We denote HÎ˜(x)kH_\Theta(x)_kHÎ˜â€‹(x)kâ€‹ as being a hypothesis that results in the KthK^{th}Kth output.

Our cost function for neural networks is going to be a generalization of the one we used for logistic regression. Recall that the cost function for regularized logistic regression was:

J(Î¸)=âˆ’1mâˆ‘i=1m[y(i)Â logâ¡(hÎ¸(x(i)))+(1âˆ’y(i))Â logâ¡(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x(i)))]+Î»2mâˆ‘j=1nÎ¸j2J(\theta) = - \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=1}^m \large[ y^{(i)}\ \log (h_\theta (x^{(i)})) + (1 - y^{(i)})\ \log (1 - h_\theta(x^{(i)}))\large] + \frac{\lambda}{2m}\sum_{j=1}^n \theta_j^2J(Î¸)=âˆ’m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[y(i)Â log(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))+(1âˆ’y(i))Â log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))]+2mÎ»â€‹âˆ‘j=1nâ€‹Î¸j2â€‹

For neural networks, it is going to be slightly more complicated:

J(Î˜)=âˆ’1mâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘k=1K[yk(i)log((hÎ˜(x(i)))k)+(1âˆ’yk(i))log(1âˆ’(hÎ˜(x(i)))k)]+Î»2mâˆ‘l=1Lâˆ’1âˆ‘i=1slâˆ‘j=1sl+1(Î˜j,i(l))2J(\Theta)=-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Big[y_k^{(i)}log\Big(\big(h_\Theta(x^{(i)})\big)_k\Big)+(1-y_k^{(i)})log\Big(1-\big(h_\Theta(x^{(i)})\big)_k\Big)\Big]+\frac{\lambda}{2m}\sum_{l=1}^{L-1}\sum_{i=1}^{s_l}\sum_{j=1}^{s_{l+1}}\Big(\Theta_{j,i}^{(l)}\Big)^2J(Î˜)=âˆ’m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹k=1âˆ‘Kâ€‹[yk(i)â€‹log((hÎ˜â€‹(x(i)))kâ€‹)+(1âˆ’yk(i)â€‹)log(1âˆ’(hÎ˜â€‹(x(i)))kâ€‹)]+2mÎ»â€‹l=1âˆ‘Lâˆ’1â€‹i=1âˆ‘slâ€‹â€‹j=1âˆ‘sl+1â€‹â€‹(Î˜j,i(l)â€‹)2

We have added a few nested summations to account for our multiple output nodes. In the first part of the equation, before the square brackets, we have an additional nested summation that loops through the number of output nodes.

In the regularization part, after the square brackets, we must account for multiple theta matrices. The number of columns in our current theta matrix is equal to the number of nodes in our current layer (including the bias unit). The number of rows in our current theta matrix is equal to the number of nodes in the next layer (excluding the bias unit). As before with logistic regression, we square every term.

Note:

  • the double sum simply adds up the logistic regression costs calculated for each cell in the output layer
  • the triple sum simply adds up the squares of all the individual Î˜s in the entire network.
  • the i in the triple sum does not refer to training example i

Backpropagation Algorithm

Backpropagation is neural-network terminology for minimizing our cost function, just like what we were doing with gradient descent in logistic and linear regression. Our goal is to compute:

minÎ˜J(Î˜)\mathop{\textrm{min}}_\Theta J(\Theta)minÎ˜â€‹J(Î˜)

That is, we want to minimize our cost function JJJ using an optimal set of parameters in theta. In this section weâ€™ll look at the equations we use to compute the partial derivative of J(Î˜)J(\Theta)J(Î˜):

âˆ‚âˆ‚Î˜i,j(l)J(Î˜)\frac{\partial}{\partial\Theta_{i,j}^{(l)}}J(\Theta)âˆ‚Î˜i,j(l)â€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î˜)

To do so, we use the following algorithm:

Backpropagation Algorithm

Given training set (x(1),y(1)),...,(x(m),y(m)){(x^{(1)},y^{(1)}),...,(x^{(m)},y^{(m)})}(x(1),y(1)),...,(x(m),y(m))

  • Set Î”i,j(l):=0\Delta_{i,j}^{(l)}:=0Î”i,j(l)â€‹:=0 for all l,i,jl,i,jl,i,j, (hence you end up having a matrix full of zeros)

(ğŸ‘‡ Begin For loop: ğŸ‘‡)

For training example t=1Â toÂ mt=1\textrm{ to } mt=1Â toÂ m:

  1. Set a(1):=x(t)a^{(1)}:=x^{(t)}a(1):=x(t)
  2. Preform forward propagation to compute a(l)a^{(l)}a(l) for l=2,3,...,Ll=2,3,...,Ll=2,3,...,L

  1. Using y(t)y^{(t)}y(t), compute Î´(L)=a(L)âˆ’y(t)\delta^{(L)}=a^{(L)}-y^{(t)}Î´(L)=a(L)âˆ’y(t)

Where LLL is our total number of layers and a(L)a^{(L)}a(L) is the vector of outputs of the activation units for the last layer.

So, our error values for the last layer are simply the differences of our actual results in the last layer and the correct outputs in yyy.

To get the delta values of the layers before the last layer, we can use an equation that steps us back from right to left:

  1. Compute Î´(Lâˆ’1),Î´(Lâˆ’2),...,Î´(2)\delta^{(L-1)},\delta^{(L-2)},...,\delta^{(2)}Î´(Lâˆ’1),Î´(Lâˆ’2),...,Î´(2) using Î´(l)=((Î˜(l))TÎ´(l+1)).âˆ—a(l).âˆ—(1âˆ’a(l))\delta^{(l)}=\big((\Theta^{(l)})^T\delta^{(l+1)}\big).*a^{(l)}.*(1-a^{(l)})Î´(l)=((Î˜(l))TÎ´(l+1)).âˆ—a(l).âˆ—(1âˆ’a(l))

ã€Noteã€‘: â€œ$.* $â€ above are the element-wise multiplications in Octave/MATLAB.

The delta values of layer lll are calculated by multiplying the delta values in the next layer with the theta matrix of layer lll.

We then element-wise multiply that with a function called gâ€²g'gâ€², or g-prime, which is the derivative of the activation function ggg evaluated with the input values given by z(l)z^{(l)}z(l).

The g-prime derivative terms can also be written out as: gâ€²(z(l))=a(l).âˆ—(1âˆ’a(l))g'(z^{(l)})=a^{(l)}.*(1-a^{(l)})gâ€²(z(l))=a(l).âˆ—(1âˆ’a(l))

  1. Î”i,j(l):=Î”i,jl+aj(l)Î´(l+1)\Delta_{i,j}^{(l)}:=\Delta_{i,j}^{l}+a_j^{(l)}\delta^{(l+1)}Î”i,j(l)â€‹:=Î”i,jlâ€‹+aj(l)â€‹Î´(l+1) or with vectorization, Î”(l):=Î”(l)+Î´(l+1)(a(l))T\Delta^{(l)}:=\Delta^{(l)}+\delta^{(l+1)}(a^{(l)})^TÎ”(l):=Î”(l)+Î´(l+1)(a(l))T

(ğŸ‘† End For ğŸ‘†)

Hence we update our new Î”\DeltaÎ” matrix.

  • Di,j(l):=1m(Î”i,j(l)+Î»Î˜i,j(l))D_{i,j}^{(l)}:=\frac{1}{m}\big(\Delta_{i,j}^{(l)}+\lambda\Theta_{i,j}^{(l)}\big)Di,j(l)â€‹:=m1â€‹(Î”i,j(l)â€‹+Î»Î˜i,j(l)â€‹), if j=Ì¸0j\not=0jî€ â€‹=0;

  • Di,j(l):=1mÎ”i,j(l)D_{i,j}^{(l)}:=\frac{1}{m}\Delta_{i,j}^{(l)}Di,j(l)â€‹:=m1â€‹Î”i,j(l)â€‹ if j=0j=0j=0.

The capital-delta matrix DDD is used as an accumulator to add up our values as we go along and eventually compute our partial derivate.

Thus we get âˆ‚âˆ‚Î˜i,j(l)J(Î˜)=Di,j(l)\frac{\partial}{\partial\Theta_{i,j}^{(l)}}J(\Theta)=D_{i,j}^{(l)}âˆ‚Î˜i,j(l)â€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î˜)=Di,j(l)â€‹.

Backpropagation Intuition

Recall that the cost function for a neural network is:

J(Î˜)=âˆ’1mâˆ‘i=1mâˆ‘k=1K[yk(t)logâ¡(hÎ˜(x(t)))k+(1âˆ’yk(t))logâ¡(1âˆ’hÎ˜(x(t)))k]+Î»mâˆ‘l=1Lâˆ’1âˆ‘i=1slâˆ‘j=1sl+1(Î˜j,i(l))2J(\Theta)=-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\Big[y_k^{(t)}\log\big(h_\Theta(x^{(t)})\big)_k+(1-y_k^{(t)})\log\big(1-h_\Theta(x^{(t)})\big)_k\Big]+\frac{\lambda}{m}\sum_{l=1}^{L-1}\sum_{i=1}^{s_l}\sum_{j=1}^{s_l+1}\Big(\Theta_{j,i}^{(l)}\Big)^2J(Î˜)=âˆ’m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹k=1âˆ‘Kâ€‹[yk(t)â€‹log(hÎ˜â€‹(x(t)))kâ€‹+(1âˆ’yk(t)â€‹)log(1âˆ’hÎ˜â€‹(x(t)))kâ€‹]+mÎ»â€‹l=1âˆ‘Lâˆ’1â€‹i=1âˆ‘slâ€‹â€‹j=1âˆ‘slâ€‹+1â€‹(Î˜j,i(l)â€‹)2

If we consider simple non-multiclass classification (K=1K=1K=1) and disregard regularization, the cost is copmputed with:

cost(t)=y(t)logâ¡(hÎ˜(x(t)))+(1âˆ’y(t))logâ¡(1âˆ’hÎ˜(x(t)))cost(t) = y^{(t)}\log\big(h_\Theta(x^{(t)})\big)+(1-y^{(t)})\log\big(1-h_\Theta(x^{(t)})\big)cost(t)=y(t)log(hÎ˜â€‹(x(t)))+(1âˆ’y(t))log(1âˆ’hÎ˜â€‹(x(t)))

Intuitively, Î´j(l)\delta_j^{(l)}Î´j(l)â€‹ is the â€œerrorâ€ for aj(l)a_j^{(l)}aj(l)â€‹ (unit jjj in layer lll). More formally, the delta values are actually the derivative of the cost function:

Î´j(l)=âˆ‚âˆ‚zj(l)cost(t)\delta_j^{(l)}=\frac{\partial}{\partial z_j^{(l)}}cost(t)Î´j(l)â€‹=âˆ‚zj(l)â€‹âˆ‚â€‹cost(t)

Recall that our derivative is the slope of a line tangent to the cost function, so the steeper the slope the more incorrect we are. Let us consider the following neural network below and see how we could calculate some Î´j(l)\delta_j^{(l)}Î´j(l)â€‹:

In the image above, to calculate Î´2(2)\delta_2^{(2)}Î´2(2)â€‹ , we multiply the weights Î˜12(2)\Theta_{12}^{(2)}Î˜12(2)â€‹ and Î˜22(2)\Theta_{22}^{(2)}Î˜22(2)â€‹ by their respective Î´\deltaÎ´ values found to the right of each edge. So we get Î´2(2)=Î˜12(2)Ã—Î´1(3)+Î˜22(2)Ã—Î´2(3)\delta_2^{(2)}=\Theta_{12}^{(2)}\times\delta_1^{(3)}+\Theta_{22}^{(2)}\times\delta_2^{(3)}Î´2(2)â€‹=Î˜12(2)â€‹Ã—Î´1(3)â€‹+Î˜22(2)â€‹Ã—Î´2(3)â€‹. To calculate every single possible Î´j(l)\delta_j^{(l)}Î´j(l)â€‹, we could start from the right of our diagram. We can think of our edges as our Î˜ij\Theta_{ij}Î˜ijâ€‹. Going from right to left, to calculate the value of Î´j(l)\delta_j^{(l)}Î´j(l)â€‹, you can just take the over all sum of each weight times the Î´\deltaÎ´ it is coming from. Hence, another example would be Î´2(3)=Î˜12(3)Ã—Î´1(4)\delta_2^{(3)}=\Theta_{12}^{(3)}\times\delta_1^{(4)}Î´2(3)â€‹=Î˜12(3)â€‹Ã—Î´1(4)â€‹.

Backpropagation in Practice

Unrolling Parameters

With neural networks, we are working with sets of matrices:

Î˜(1),Î˜(2),Î˜(3),â€¦D(1),D(2),D(3),â€¦\begin{array}{lll} \Theta^{(1)}, \Theta^{(2)}, \Theta^{(3)}, \dots \newline D^{(1)}, D^{(2)}, D^{(3)}, \dots \end{array}Î˜(1),Î˜(2),Î˜(3),â€¦D(1),D(2),D(3),â€¦â€‹

In order to use optimizing function such as fminunc(), we will want to unroll all the elements and put them into one long vector:

If the dimensions of Theta1 is 10x11, Theta2 is 10x11 and Theta3 is 1x11, then we can get back our original matrices from the â€œunrolledâ€ versions as follows:

To summarize:

Gradient Checking

Gradient checking will assure that our backpropagation works as intended. We can approximate the derivative of our cost function with:

âˆ‚âˆ‚Î˜J(Î˜)â‰ˆJ(Î˜+Ïµ)âˆ’J(Î˜âˆ’Ïµ)2Ïµ\frac{\partial}{\partial\Theta}J(\Theta) \approx \frac{J(\Theta+\epsilon)-J(\Theta-\epsilon)}{2\epsilon}âˆ‚Î˜âˆ‚â€‹J(Î˜)â‰ˆ2ÏµJ(Î˜+Ïµ)âˆ’J(Î˜âˆ’Ïµ)â€‹

A small value for Ïµ\epsilonÏµ such as Ïµ=10âˆ’4\epsilon=10^{-4}Ïµ=10âˆ’4, guarantees that the math works out properly. If the value for Ïµ\epsilonÏµ, we can end up with numerical problems.

With multiple theta matrices, we can approximate the derivative with respect to Î˜j\Theta_jÎ˜jâ€‹ (where we get jjj from 1 to n, for each one) as follows:

âˆ‚âˆ‚Î˜jJ(Î˜)â‰ˆJ(Î˜1,...,Î˜j+Ïµ,...,Î˜n)âˆ’J(Î˜1,...,Î˜jâˆ’Ïµ,...,Î˜n)2Ïµ\frac{\partial}{\partial\Theta_j}J(\Theta) \approx \frac{J(\Theta_1,...,\Theta_j+\epsilon,...,\Theta_n)-J(\Theta_1,...,\Theta_j-\epsilon,...,\Theta_n)}{2\epsilon}âˆ‚Î˜jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î˜)â‰ˆ2ÏµJ(Î˜1â€‹,...,Î˜jâ€‹+Ïµ,...,Î˜nâ€‹)âˆ’J(Î˜1â€‹,...,Î˜jâ€‹âˆ’Ïµ,...,Î˜nâ€‹)â€‹

Hence, we are only adding or subtracting epsilon to the Î˜j\Theta_jÎ˜jâ€‹ matrix.

In octave we can do it as follows:

We previously saw how to calculate the deltaVector. So once we compute our gradApprox vector, we can check that gradApprox â‰ˆ deltaVector.

Once we have verified once that your backpropagation algorithm is correct, we donâ€™t need to compute gradApprox again. The code to compute gradApprox can be very slow. So we guess itâ€™s better to turn off or disable the codes for gradient checking.

Randoom Initialization

Initializing all theta weights to zero does not work with neural networks. When we backpropagate, all nodes will update to the same value repeatedly. Instead we can randomly initialize our weights for our Î˜\ThetaÎ˜ matrices using the following method:

Hence, we initialize each Î˜ij(l)\Theta_{ij}^{(l)}Î˜ij(l)â€‹ to a random value between [âˆ’Ïµ,Ïµ][-\epsilon,\epsilon][âˆ’Ïµ,Ïµ]. Using the above formula guarantees that we get the desired bound. The same procedure applies to all the Î˜\ThetaÎ˜'s.

Below is some working code implement.

rand(x,y) is just a function in octave that will initialize a matrix of random real numbers between 0 and 1.

(Note: the epsilon used above is unrelated to the epsilon from Gradient Checking)

Putting It Together

First, pick a network architecture; choose the layout of your neural network, including how many hidden units in each layer and how many layers in total you want to have.

  • Number of input units = dimension of features x(i)x^{(i)}x(i)
  • Number of output units = number of classes
  • Number of hidden units per layer = usually more the better (must balance with cost of computation as it increases with more hidden units)
  • Defaults: 1 hidden layer. If you have more than 1 hidden layer, then it is recommended that you have the same number of units in every hidden layer.

Training a Neural Network

  1. Randomly initialize the weights
  2. Implement forward propagation to get hÎ˜(x(i)) for any x(i)x(i)
  3. Implement the cost function
  4. Implement backpropagation to compute partial derivatives
  5. Use gradient checking to confirm that your backpropagation works. Then disable gradient checking.
  6. Use gradient descent or a built-in optimization function to minimize the cost function with the weights in theta.

When we perform forward and back propagation, we loop on every training example:

The following image gives us an intuition of what is happening as we are implementing our neural network:

Ideally, we want hÎ˜(x(i))â‰ˆy(i)h_\Theta(x^{(i)})\approx y^{(i)}hÎ˜â€‹(x(i))â‰ˆy(i). This will minimize our cost function. However, keep in mind that J(Î˜)J(\Theta)J(Î˜) is not convex and thus we can end up in a local minimum instead.

entry.title: ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„æè¿°
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (8) Neural Networks: Representation

Model Representation

Letâ€™s examine how we will represent a hypothesis function using neural networks.

At a very simple level, neurons are basically computational units that take inputs (dendrites) as electrical inputs (called â€œspikesâ€) that are channeled to outputs (axons).

In our model, our dendrites are like the input features x1â‹¯xnx_1\cdots x_nx1â€‹â‹¯xnâ€‹, and the output is the result of our hypothesis function.

In this model our x0x_0x0â€‹ input node is sometimes called the â€œbias unit.â€ It is always equal to 1.

In neural networks, we use the same logistic function as in classification, 11+eâˆ’Î¸Tx\frac{1}{1+e^{-\theta^Tx}}1+eâˆ’Î¸Tx1â€‹, yet we sometimes call it a sigmoid (logistic) activation function. In this situation, our â€œthetaâ€ parameters are sometimes called â€œweightsâ€.

Visually, a simplistic representation looks like:

[x0x1x2]â†’[]â†’hÎ¸(x)\left[\begin{array}{c}x_0\\x_1\\x_2\end{array}\right]\to [\quad] \to h_\theta(x)â£â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹â¦â¤â€‹â†’[]â†’hÎ¸â€‹(x)

Our input nodes (layer 1), also known as the â€œinput layerâ€, go into another node (layer 2), which finally outputs the hypothesis function, known as the â€œoutput layerâ€. We can have intermediate layers of nodes between the input and output layers called the â€œhidden layers.â€

In this example, we label these intermediate or â€œhiddenâ€ layer nodes a02â‹¯an2a^2_0 \cdots a^2_na02â€‹â‹¯an2â€‹ and call them â€œactivation units.â€

  • ai(j)a_i^{(j)}ai(j)â€‹ = â€œactivationâ€ of unit iii in layer jjj
  • Î˜(j)\Theta^{(j)}Î˜(j) = matrix of weights controlling function mapping from layer jjj to layer j+1j+1j+1

If we had one hidden layer, it would look like:

[x0x1x2x3]â†’[a1(2)a2(2)a3(2)]â†’hÎ¸(x)\left[\begin{array}{c}x_0 \\ x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3\end{array}\right]\rightarrow\left[\begin{array}{c}a_1^{(2)} \\ a_2^{(2)} \\ a_3^{(2)} \\ \end{array}\right]\rightarrow h_\theta(x)â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹x2â€‹x3â€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹â†’â£â¢â¡â€‹a1(2)â€‹a2(2)â€‹a3(2)â€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹â†’hÎ¸â€‹(x)

The values for each of the â€œactivationâ€ nodes is obtained as follows:

a1(2)=g(Î˜10(1)x0+Î˜11(1)x1+Î˜12(1)x2+Î˜13(1)x3)a2(2)=g(Î˜20(1)x0+Î˜21(1)x1+Î˜22(1)x2+Î˜23(1)x3)a3(2)=g(Î˜30(1)x0+Î˜31(1)x1+Î˜32(1)x2+Î˜33(1)x3)hÎ˜(x)=a1(3)=g(Î˜10(2)a0(2)+Î˜11(2)a1(2)+Î˜12(2)a2(2)+Î˜13(2)a3(2))\begin{array}{r} a_1^{(2)} = g(\Theta_{10}^{(1)}x_0 + \Theta_{11}^{(1)}x_1 + \Theta_{12}^{(1)}x_2 + \Theta_{13}^{(1)}x_3) \\\\ a_2^{(2)} = g(\Theta_{20}^{(1)}x_0 + \Theta_{21}^{(1)}x_1 + \Theta_{22}^{(1)}x_2 + \Theta_{23}^{(1)}x_3) \\\\ a_3^{(2)} = g(\Theta_{30}^{(1)}x_0 + \Theta_{31}^{(1)}x_1 + \Theta_{32}^{(1)}x_2 + \Theta_{33}^{(1)}x_3) \\\\ h_\Theta(x) = a_1^{(3)} = g(\Theta_{10}^{(2)}a_0^{(2)} + \Theta_{11}^{(2)}a_1^{(2)} + \Theta_{12}^{(2)}a_2^{(2)} + \Theta_{13}^{(2)}a_3^{(2)}) \\\\ \end{array}a1(2)â€‹=g(Î˜10(1)â€‹x0â€‹+Î˜11(1)â€‹x1â€‹+Î˜12(1)â€‹x2â€‹+Î˜13(1)â€‹x3â€‹)a2(2)â€‹=g(Î˜20(1)â€‹x0â€‹+Î˜21(1)â€‹x1â€‹+Î˜22(1)â€‹x2â€‹+Î˜23(1)â€‹x3â€‹)a3(2)â€‹=g(Î˜30(1)â€‹x0â€‹+Î˜31(1)â€‹x1â€‹+Î˜32(1)â€‹x2â€‹+Î˜33(1)â€‹x3â€‹)hÎ˜â€‹(x)=a1(3)â€‹=g(Î˜10(2)â€‹a0(2)â€‹+Î˜11(2)â€‹a1(2)â€‹+Î˜12(2)â€‹a2(2)â€‹+Î˜13(2)â€‹a3(2)â€‹)â€‹

To do a vectorized implementation of thew above functions, weâ€™re going to define a new variable zk(j)z_k^{(j)}zk(j)â€‹ that encompasses the parameters inside our ggg function. In the previous example if we replaced by the vartizble zzz for all the parameters we would get:

a1(2)=g(z1(2))a2(2)=g(z2(2))a3(2)=g(z3(2))\begin{array}{l}a_1^{(2)} = g(z_1^{(2)}) \\\\ a_2^{(2)} = g(z_2^{(2)}) \\\\ a_3^{(2)} = g(z_3^{(2)}) \\\\ \end{array}a1(2)â€‹=g(z1(2)â€‹)a2(2)â€‹=g(z2(2)â€‹)a3(2)â€‹=g(z3(2)â€‹)â€‹

In other words, for layer j=2j=2j=2 and node kkk, the variable zzz will be:

zk(2)=Î˜k,0(1)x0+Î˜k,1(1)x1+â‹¯+Î˜k,n(1)xnz_k^{(2)} = \Theta_{k,0}^{(1)}x_0 + \Theta_{k,1}^{(1)}x_1 + \cdots + \Theta_{k,n}^{(1)}x_nzk(2)â€‹=Î˜k,0(1)â€‹x0â€‹+Î˜k,1(1)â€‹x1â€‹+â‹¯+Î˜k,n(1)â€‹xnâ€‹

The vector representation of xxx and zjz^{j}zj is:

x=[x0x1â‹®xn]z(j)=[z1(j)z2(j)â‹®zn(j)]x = \begin{bmatrix}x_0 \\ x_1 \\ \vdots \\ x_n\end{bmatrix} \qquad z^{(j)} = \begin{bmatrix}z_1^{(j)} \\ z_2^{(j)} \\ \vdots \\ z_n^{(j)}\end{bmatrix}x=â£â¢â¢â¢â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹â‹®xnâ€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¥â¤â€‹z(j)=â£â¢â¢â¢â¢â¡â€‹z1(j)â€‹z2(j)â€‹â‹®zn(j)â€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¥â¥â¤â€‹

Setting x=a(1)x = a^{(1)}x=a(1), we can rewrite the equation as:

z(j)=Î˜(jâˆ’1)a(jâˆ’1)z^{(j)} = \Theta^{(j-1)}a^{(j-1)}z(j)=Î˜(jâˆ’1)a(jâˆ’1)

We are multiplying our matrix Î˜(jâˆ’1)\Theta^{(jâˆ’1)}Î˜(jâˆ’1) with dimensions sjÃ—(n+1)s_j\times (n+1)sjâ€‹Ã—(n+1) (where sjs_jsjâ€‹ is the number of our activation nodes) by our vector a(jâˆ’1)a^{(j-1)}a(jâˆ’1) with height (n+1)(n+1)(n+1). This gives us our vector z(j)z^{(j)}z(j) with height sjs_jsjâ€‹. Now we can get a vector of our activation nodes for layer jjj as follows:

a(j)=g(z(j))a^{(j)} = g(z^{(j)})a(j)=g(z(j))

Where our function g can be applied element-wise to our vector z(j)z^{(j)}z(j).

We can then add a bias unit (equal to 111) to layer jjj after we have computed a(j)a^{(j)}a(j). This will be element a0(j)a_0^{(j)}a0(j)â€‹ and will be equal to 111. To compute our final hypothesis, letâ€™s first compute another zzz vector:

z(j+1)=Î˜(j)a(j)z^{(j+1)} = \Theta^{(j)}a^{(j)}z(j+1)=Î˜(j)a(j)

We get this final zzz vector by multiplying the next theta matrix after Î˜(jâˆ’1)\Theta^{(jâˆ’1)}Î˜(jâˆ’1) with the values of all the activation nodes we just got. This last theta matrix Î˜(j)\Theta^{(j)}Î˜(j) will have only one row which is multiplied by one column a(j)a^{(j)}a(j) so that our result is a single number. We then get our final result with:

hÎ˜(x)=a(j+1)=g(z(j+1))h_\Theta(x)=a^{(j+1)}=g(z^{(j+1)})hÎ˜â€‹(x)=a(j+1)=g(z(j+1))

Notice that in this last step, between layer jjj and layer j+1j+1j+1, we are doing exactly the same thing as we did in logistic regression. Adding all these intermediate layers in neural networks allows us to more elegantly produce interesting and more complex non-linear hypotheses.

Examples and Intuitions

A simple example of applying neural networks is by predicting x_1 \and x_2, which is the logical â€˜andâ€™ operator and is only true if both x1x_1x1â€‹ and x2x_2x2â€‹ are 111. The graph of our functions will look like:

[x0x1x2]â†’[g(z(2))]â†’hÎ˜(x)\begin{array}{c}\begin{bmatrix}x_0 \\ x_1 \\ x_2\end{bmatrix} \rightarrow\begin{bmatrix}g(z^{(2)})\end{bmatrix} \rightarrow h_\Theta(x)\end{array}â£â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹â¦â¤â€‹â†’[g(z(2))â€‹]â†’hÎ˜â€‹(x)â€‹

Remember that x0x_0x0â€‹ is our bias variable and is always 111. The g(z)g(z)g(z) is the following:

Letâ€™s set our first Theta matrix as:

Î˜(1)=[âˆ’302020]\Theta^{(1)}=\begin{bmatrix} -30 & 20 & 20 \end{bmatrix}Î˜(1)=[âˆ’30â€‹20â€‹20â€‹]

This will cause the output of our hypothesis to only be positive if both x1x_1x1â€‹ and x2x_2x2â€‹ are 111. In other words:

hÎ˜(x)=g(âˆ’30+20x1+20x2)x1=0Â Â andÂ Â x2=0Â Â thenÂ Â g(âˆ’30)â‰ˆ0x1=0Â Â andÂ Â x2=1Â Â thenÂ Â g(âˆ’10)â‰ˆ0x1=1Â Â andÂ Â x2=0Â Â thenÂ Â g(âˆ’10)â‰ˆ0x1=1Â Â andÂ Â x2=1Â Â thenÂ Â g(10)â‰ˆ1\begin{array}{ll}& h_\Theta(x) = g(-30 + 20x_1 + 20x_2) \\ \\ & x_1 = 0 \ \ and \ \ x_2 = 0 \ \ then \ \ g(-30) \approx 0 \\ & x_1 = 0 \ \ and \ \ x_2 = 1 \ \ then \ \ g(-10) \approx 0 \\ & x_1 = 1 \ \ and \ \ x_2 = 0 \ \ then \ \ g(-10) \approx 0 \\ & x_1 = 1 \ \ and \ \ x_2 = 1 \ \ then \ \ g(10) \approx 1\end{array}â€‹hÎ˜â€‹(x)=g(âˆ’30+20x1â€‹+20x2â€‹)x1â€‹=0Â Â andÂ Â x2â€‹=0Â Â thenÂ Â g(âˆ’30)â‰ˆ0x1â€‹=0Â Â andÂ Â x2â€‹=1Â Â thenÂ Â g(âˆ’10)â‰ˆ0x1â€‹=1Â Â andÂ Â x2â€‹=0Â Â thenÂ Â g(âˆ’10)â‰ˆ0x1â€‹=1Â Â andÂ Â x2â€‹=1Â Â thenÂ Â g(10)â‰ˆ1â€‹

So we have constructed one of the fundamental operations in computers by using a small neural network rather than using an actual AND gate. Neural networks can also be used to simulate all the other logical gates. The following is an example of the logical operator â€˜ORâ€™, meaning either x1x_1x1â€‹ is true or x2x_2x2â€‹ is true, or both:

A Neural Network for XNOR

The Î˜(1)\Theta^{(1)}Î˜(1) matrices for AND, NOR and OR are:

AND:Î˜(1)=[âˆ’302020]NOR:Î˜(1)=[10âˆ’20âˆ’20]OR:Î˜(1)=[âˆ’102020]\begin{array}{l}AND:\\&\Theta^{(1)} &=\begin{bmatrix}-30 & 20 & 20\end{bmatrix} \\ NOR:\\&\Theta^{(1)} &= \begin{bmatrix}10 & -20 & -20\end{bmatrix} \\ OR:\\&\Theta^{(1)} &= \begin{bmatrix}-10 & 20 & 20\end{bmatrix} \\\end{array}AND:NOR:OR:â€‹Î˜(1)Î˜(1)Î˜(1)â€‹=[âˆ’30â€‹20â€‹20â€‹]=[10â€‹âˆ’20â€‹âˆ’20â€‹]=[âˆ’10â€‹20â€‹20â€‹]â€‹

We can combine these to get the XNOR logical operator (which gives 111 if x1x_1x1â€‹ and x2x_2x2â€‹ are both 000 or both 111):

[x0x1x2]â†’[a1(2)a2(2)]â†’[a(3)]â†’hÎ˜(x)\begin{bmatrix}x_0 \\ x_1 \\ x_2\end{bmatrix} \rightarrow\begin{bmatrix}a_1^{(2)} \\ a_2^{(2)} \end{bmatrix} \rightarrow\begin{bmatrix}a^{(3)}\end{bmatrix} \rightarrow h_\Theta(x)â£â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹x2â€‹â€‹â¦â¤â€‹â†’[a1(2)â€‹a2(2)â€‹â€‹]â†’[a(3)â€‹]â†’hÎ˜â€‹(x)

For the transition between the first and second layer, weâ€™ll use a Î˜(1)\Theta^{(1)}Î˜(1) matrix that combines the values for AND and NOR:

Î˜(1)=[âˆ’30202010âˆ’20âˆ’20]\Theta^{(1)} =\begin{bmatrix}-30 & 20 & 20 \\ 10 & -20 & -20\end{bmatrix}Î˜(1)=[âˆ’3010â€‹20âˆ’20â€‹20âˆ’20â€‹]

For the transition between the second and third layer, weâ€™ll use a Î˜(2)\Theta^{(2)}Î˜(2) matrix that uses the value for OR:

Î˜(2)=[âˆ’102020]\Theta^{(2)} =\begin{bmatrix}-10 & 20 & 20\end{bmatrix}Î˜(2)=[âˆ’10â€‹20â€‹20â€‹]

Letâ€™s write out the values for all our nodes:

a(2)=g(Î˜(1)â‹…x)a(3)=g(Î˜(2)â‹…a(2))hÎ˜(x)=a(3)\begin{array}{ll}& a^{(2)} = g(\Theta^{(1)} \cdot x) \\& a^{(3)} = g(\Theta^{(2)} \cdot a^{(2)}) \\& h_\Theta(x) = a^{(3)}\end{array}â€‹a(2)=g(Î˜(1)â‹…x)a(3)=g(Î˜(2)â‹…a(2))hÎ˜â€‹(x)=a(3)â€‹

And there we have the XNOR operator using a hidden layer with two nodes! The following summarizes the above algorithm:

Multiclass Classification

To classify data into multiple classes, we let our hypothesis function return a vector of values. Say we wanted to classify our data into one of four categories. We will use the following example to see how this classification is done. This algorithm takes as input an image and classifies it accordingly:

We can define our set of resulting classes as y:

y(i)=[1000],[0100],[0010],[0001]y^{(i)}=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\0\\0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\0\\0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\1\\0\end{bmatrix},\begin{bmatrix}0\\0\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}y(i)=â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹1000â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹,â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹0100â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹,â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹0010â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹,â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹0001â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹

Each y(i)y^{(i)}y(i) represents a different image corresponding to either a car, pedestrian, truck, or motorcycle. The inner layers, each provide us with some new information which leads to our final hypothesis function. The setup looks like:

Our resulting hypothesis for one set of inputs may look like:

hÎ˜(x)=[0010]h_\Theta(x) =\begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}hÎ˜â€‹(x)=â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹0010â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹

In which case our resulting class is the third one down, or hÎ˜(x)3h_{\Theta}(x)_3hÎ˜â€‹(x)3â€‹, which represents the motorcycle.

entry.title: è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆ
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (7) Overfitting

The Problem of Overfitting

Consider the problem of predicting yyy from xâˆˆRx \in \RxâˆˆR. The leftmost figure below shows the result of fitting a y=Î¸0+Î¸1xy=\theta_0+\theta_1xy=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x to a dataset. We see that the data doesnâ€™t really lie on straight line, and so the fit is not very good.

Instead, if we had added an extra feature x2x^2x2, and fit y=Î¸0+Î¸1+Î¸2x2y=\theta_0+\theta_1+\theta_2x^2y=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹+Î¸2â€‹x2, then we obtain a slightly better fit to the data (See middle figure).

Naively, it might seem that the more features we add, the better. However, there is also a danger in adding too many features: The rightmost figure is the result of fitting a 5th5^{th}5th order polynomial y=âˆ‘j=05Î¸jxjy = \sum_{j=0} ^5 \theta_j x^jy=âˆ‘j=05â€‹Î¸jâ€‹xj. We see that even though the fitted curve passes through the data perfectly, we would not expect this to be a very good predictor for unseen examples.

The figure on the left shows an instance of underfittingâ€”in which the data clearly shows structure not captured by the model

Underfitting, or high bias, is when the form of our hypothesis function h maps poorly to the trend of the data. It is usually caused by a function that is too simple or uses too few features.

The figure on the right is an example of overfitting.

Overfitting, or high variance, is caused by a hypothesis function that makes accurate predictions for examples in the training set, but it does not generalize well to make accurate predictions on new, previously unseen examples. It is usually caused by a complicated function that creates a lot of unnecessary curves and angles unrelated to the data.

Overfitting is applied to both linear and logistic regression. There are two main options to address the issue of overfitting:

  1. Reduce the number of features:
  • Manually select which features to keep.
  • Use a model selection algorithm (studied later in the course).
  1. Regularization
  • Keep all the features, but reduce the magnitude of parameters Î¸j\theta_jÎ¸jâ€‹.
  • Regularization works well when we have a lot of slightly useful features.

Cost Function

If we have overfitting from our hypothesis function, we can reduce the weight that some of the terms in our function carry by increasing their cost.

Say we wanted to make the following function more quadratic:

Î¸0+Î¸1x+Î¸2x2+Î¸3x3+Î¸4x4\theta_0 + \theta_1x + \theta_2x^2 + \theta_3x^3 + \theta_4x^4Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x+Î¸2â€‹x2+Î¸3â€‹x3+Î¸4â€‹x4

Weâ€™ll want to eliminate the influence of Î¸3x3\theta_3x^3Î¸3â€‹x3 and Î¸4x4\theta_4x^4Î¸4â€‹x4 . Without actually getting rid of these features or changing the form of our hypothesis, we can instead modify our cost function:

minÎ¸Â 12mâˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2+1000â‹…Î¸32+1000â‹…Î¸42min_\theta\ \dfrac{1}{2m}\sum_{i=1}^m (h_\theta(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2 + 1000\cdot\theta_3^2 + 1000\cdot\theta_4^2minÎ¸â€‹Â 2m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2+1000â‹…Î¸32â€‹+1000â‹…Î¸42â€‹

Weâ€™ve added two extra terms at the end to inflate the cost of Î¸3\theta_3Î¸3â€‹ and Î¸4\theta_4Î¸4â€‹. Now, in order for the cost function to get close to zero, we will have to reduce the values of Î¸3\theta_3Î¸3â€‹ and Î¸4\theta_4Î¸4â€‹ to near zero. This will in turn greatly reduce the values of Î¸3x3\theta_3x^3Î¸3â€‹x3 and Î¸4x4\theta_4x^4Î¸4â€‹x4 in our hypothesis function. As a result, we see that the new hypothesis (depicted by the pink curve) looks like a quadratic function but fits the data better due to the extra small terms Î¸3x3\theta_3x^3Î¸3â€‹x3 and Î¸4x4\theta_4x^4Î¸4â€‹x4.

We could also regularize all of our theta parameters in a single summation as:

minÎ¸12mÂ âˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2+Î»Â âˆ‘j=1nÎ¸j2\mathop{min}\limits_{\theta} \dfrac{1}{2m}\ \sum_{i=1}^m (h_\theta(x^{(i)}) - y^{(i)})^2 + \lambda\ \sum_{j=1}^n \theta_j^2Î¸minâ€‹2m1â€‹Â i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2+Î»Â j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Î¸j2â€‹

The Î»\lambdaÎ», or lambda, is the regularization parameter. It determines how much the costs of our theta parameters are inflated.

Using the above cost function with the extra summation, we can smooth the output of our hypothesis function to reduce overfitting.

Note. If lambda is chosen to be too large, it may smooth out the function too much and cause underfitting.

Regularized Linear Regression

We can apply regularization to both linear regression and logistic regression.

Gradient Descent

We will modify our gradient descent function to separate out Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ from the rest of the parameters because we do not want to penalize Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹.

Repeat{Î¸0:=Î¸0âˆ’Î±1mâˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))x0(i)Î¸j:=Î¸jâˆ’Î±[(1mâˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))xji)+Î»mÎ¸j]jâˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯â€‰,n}}\begin{array}{l}Repeat\quad\{\\\qquad \theta_0:=\theta_0-\alpha\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m\big(h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}\big)x_0^{(i)}\\\qquad \theta_j:=\theta_j-\alpha\Big[\Big(\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m\big(h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}\big)x_j^{i}\Big)+\frac{\lambda}{m}\theta_j\Big]\qquad j\in\{1,2,\cdots,n\}\\\}\end{array}Repeat{Î¸0â€‹:=Î¸0â€‹âˆ’Î±m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))x0(i)â€‹Î¸jâ€‹:=Î¸jâ€‹âˆ’Î±[(m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))xjiâ€‹)+mÎ»â€‹Î¸jâ€‹]jâˆˆ{1,2,â‹¯,n}}â€‹

The term Î»mÎ¸j\frac{\lambda}{m}\theta_jmÎ»â€‹Î¸jâ€‹ performs our regularization. With some manipulation our update rule can also be represented as:

Î¸j:=Î¸j(1âˆ’Î±Î»m)âˆ’Î±1mâˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))xj(i)\theta_j:=\theta_j(1-\alpha\frac{\lambda}{m})-\alpha\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}\Big(h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}\Big)x_j^{(i)}Î¸jâ€‹:=Î¸jâ€‹(1âˆ’Î±mÎ»â€‹)âˆ’Î±m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))xj(i)â€‹

The first term in the above equation, (1âˆ’Î±Î»m)(1-\alpha\frac{\lambda}{m})(1âˆ’Î±mÎ»â€‹) will always be less than 111. Intuitively we can see it as reducing the value of Î¸j\theta_jÎ¸jâ€‹ by some amount on every update. Notice that the second term is now exactly the same as it was before.

Normal Equation

Now letâ€™s approach regularization using the alternate method of the non-iterative normal equation.

To add in regularization, the equation is the same as our original, except that we add another term inside the parentheses:

Î¸=(XTX+Î»â‹…L)âˆ’1XTywhereL=[011â‹±1]\begin{array}{l}\theta=(X^TX+\lambda \cdot L)^{-1}X^Ty\\\textrm{where}\quad L=\left[\begin{array}{cccc}0\\&1\\&&1\\&&&\ddots\\&&&&1\end{array}\right]\end{array}Î¸=(XTX+Î»â‹…L)âˆ’1XTywhereL=â£â¢â¢â¢â¢â¡â€‹0â€‹1â€‹1â€‹â‹±â€‹1â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¥â¥â¤â€‹â€‹

LLL is a matrix with 000 at the top left and 111's down the diagonal, with 000's everywhere else. It should have dimension (n+1)Ã—(n+1)(n+1)Ã—(n+1)(n+1)Ã—(n+1). Intuitively, this is the identity matrix (though we are not including x0x_0x0â€‹), multiplied with a single real number Î».

Recall that if m<nm<nm<n, then XTXX^TXXTX is non-invertible. However, when we add the term Î»â‹…L\lambda\cdot LÎ»â‹…L, then XTX+Î»â‹…LX^TX+\lambda\cdot LXTX+Î»â‹…L becomes invertible.

Regularized Logistic Regression

We can regularize logistic regression in a similar way that we regularize linear regression. As a result, we can avoid overfitting. The following image shows how the regularized function, displayed by the pink line, is less likely to overfit than the non-regularized function represented by the blue line:

Recall that our cost function for logistic regression was:

J(Î¸)=âˆ’1mâˆ‘i=1m[y(i)Â logâ¡(hÎ¸(x(i)))+(1âˆ’y(i))Â logâ¡(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x(i)))]J(\theta) = - \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=1}^m \Big[ y^{(i)}\ \log \big(h_\theta (x^{(i)})\big) + (1 - y^{(i)})\ \log \big(1 - h_\theta(x^{(i)})\big) \Big]J(Î¸)=âˆ’m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[y(i)Â log(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))+(1âˆ’y(i))Â log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))]

We can regularize this equation by adding a term to the end:

J(Î¸)=âˆ’1mâˆ‘i=1m[y(i)Â logâ¡(hÎ¸(x(i)))+(1âˆ’y(i))Â logâ¡(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x(i)))]+Î»2mâˆ‘j=1nÎ¸j2J(\theta) = - \frac{1}{m} \sum_{i=1}^m \large[ y^{(i)}\ \log (h_\theta (x^{(i)})) + (1 - y^{(i)})\ \log (1 - h_\theta(x^{(i)}))\large] + \frac{\lambda}{2m}\sum_{j=1}^n \theta_j^2J(Î¸)=âˆ’m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[y(i)Â log(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))+(1âˆ’y(i))Â log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))]+2mÎ»â€‹j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Î¸j2â€‹

The second sum, âˆ‘j=1nÎ¸j2\sum_{j=1}^n \theta_j^2âˆ‘j=1nâ€‹Î¸j2â€‹ means to explicitly exclude the bias term, Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹. I.e. the Î¸\thetaÎ¸ vector is indexed from 000 to nnn (holding n+1n+1n+1 values, Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ through Î¸n\theta_nÎ¸nâ€‹), and this sum explicitly skips Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹, by running from 111 to nnn, skipping 000. Thus, when computing the equation, we should continuously update the two following equations:

entry.title: åˆ†ç±»é—®é¢˜
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (6) Classification

Intro of Classification

Classification problems are something like giving a patient with a tumor, we have to predict whether the tumor is malignant or benign. Itâ€™s expected to output discrete values.

The classification problem is just like the regression problem, except that the values we want to predict take on only a small number of discrete values. For now, we will focus on the binary classification problem in which y can take only two values, 0 and 1.

For instance, if we are trying to build a spam classifier for email, then x(i)x^{(i)}x(i) may be some features of a piece of email, and yyy may be 1 if it is a piece of spam mail, and 0 otherwise. Hence, yâˆˆ{0,1}y \in \{0,1\}yâˆˆ{0,1}. 0 is also called the negative class, and 1 the positive class, and they are sometimes also denoted by the symbols - and +. Given x(i)x^{(i)}x(i), the corresponding y(i)y^{(i)}y(i) is also called the label for the training example.

To attempt classification, one method is to use linear refression and map all predictions greater than 0.5 as a 1 and all less than 0.5 as a 0. However, this method doesnâ€™t work because classification is not actually a linear function. So what we actually do to solve classification problems is an algorithm named logistic regression. Note that even be called regression, it is actually to do classification.

Logistic Regression

Hypothesis Representation

We could approach the classification problem ignoring the fact that y is discrete-valued, and use our old linear regression algorithm to try to predict y given x. However it is easy to construct examples where this method performs very poorly.

Intuitively, it also doesnâ€™t make sense for hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) to take values larger than 1 or smaller then 0 when we know that yâˆˆ{0,1}y\in\{0,1\}yâˆˆ{0,1}. To fix this, letâ€™s change our hypotheses hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) to satisfy 0â‰¤hÎ¸(x)â‰¤10 \le h_\theta(x) \le 10â‰¤hÎ¸â€‹(x)â‰¤1. This accomplished by plugging Î¸Tx\theta^TxÎ¸Tx into the Logistic Function.

The the Simoid Function, also called the Logistic Function is this:

y=11+eâˆ’xy = \frac{1}{1+e^{-x}}y=1+eâˆ’x1â€‹

It looks like the following image:

Our new form uses the Simoid Function:

hÎ¸(x)=g(Î¸Tx)z=Î¸Txg(z)=11+eâˆ’z\begin{array}{l}h_\theta(x) = g(\theta^Tx)\\z = \theta^Tx\\g(z) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}}\end{array}hÎ¸â€‹(x)=g(Î¸Tx)z=Î¸Txg(z)=1+eâˆ’z1â€‹â€‹

The logistic function g(z)g(z)g(z) maps any real numbers to the (0,1)(0,1)(0,1) interval, making it useful for transforming a arbitrary-valued function into a function better suited for classfication.

We can also simply write hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) like this:

hÎ¸(X)=11+eâˆ’Î¸Txh_\theta(X) = \frac{1}{1+e^{-\theta^Tx}}hÎ¸â€‹(X)=1+eâˆ’Î¸Tx1â€‹

hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) will output the probalility that our output is 1. For example, hÎ¸(x)=0.7h_\theta(x)=0.7hÎ¸â€‹(x)=0.7 gives us a probability of 70%70\%70% that our output is 111 (then the probability that it is 0 is 30%):

hÎ¸(x)=P(y=1âˆ£x;Î¸)=1âˆ’P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)+P(y=1âˆ£x;Î¸)=1\begin{array}{l}h_\theta(x)=P(y=1 \mid x;\theta)=1-P(y=0 \mid x; \theta)\\P(y=0 \mid x;\theta) + P(y=1 \mid x;\theta) = 1\end{array}hÎ¸â€‹(x)=P(y=1âˆ£x;Î¸)=1âˆ’P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)+P(y=1âˆ£x;Î¸)=1â€‹

Decision Boundary

In order to get our discrete 0 or 1 classification, we can translate the output of the hyporithesis function as follows:

hÎ¸(x)â‰¥0.5â‡’y=1hÎ¸(x)<0.5â‡’y=0\begin{array}{rcl}h_\theta(x) \ge 0.5 &\Rightarrow& y=1\\h_\theta(x) < 0.5 &\Rightarrow& y=0\end{array}hÎ¸â€‹(x)â‰¥0.5hÎ¸â€‹(x)<0.5â€‹â‡’â‡’â€‹y=1y=0â€‹

The way our logistic function ggg behaves is that when its input is â‰¥0\ge 0â‰¥0, its output is â‰¥0.5\ge 0.5â‰¥0.5:

g(z)â‰¥0.5whenzâ‰¥0g(z) \ge 0.5 \quad when \quad z \ge 0g(z)â‰¥0.5whenzâ‰¥0

In fact, we know that:

zâ†’âˆ’âˆ,eâˆâ†’âˆâ‡’g(z)â†’0zâ†’0,e0â†’1â‡’g(z)â†’0.5zâ†’+âˆ,eâˆ’âˆâ†’0â‡’g(z)â†’1\begin{array}{lclcl}z \to -\infin &,& e^{\infin} \to \infin & \Rightarrow & g(z) \to 0\\z \to 0 &,& e^{0} \to 1 & \Rightarrow & g(z) \to 0.5\\z \to +\infin &,& e^{-\infin} \to 0 & \Rightarrow & g(z) \to 1\end{array}zâ†’âˆ’âˆzâ†’0zâ†’+âˆâ€‹,,,â€‹eâˆâ†’âˆe0â†’1eâˆ’âˆâ†’0â€‹â‡’â‡’â‡’â€‹g(z)â†’0g(z)â†’0.5g(z)â†’1â€‹

So if our input to ggg is Î¸TX\theta^TXÎ¸TX, then that means:

hÎ¸(X)=g(Î¸TX)â‰¥0.5whenÎ¸TXâ‰¥0h_\theta(X) = g(\theta^TX) \ge 0.5 \quad when \quad \theta^TX \ge 0hÎ¸â€‹(X)=g(Î¸TX)â‰¥0.5whenÎ¸TXâ‰¥0

From these statements we can now say:

Î¸TXâ‰¥0â‡’y=1Î¸TXâ‰¤0â‡’y=0\begin{array}{rcl}\theta^TX \ge 0 &\Rightarrow& y=1\\\theta^TX \le 0 &\Rightarrow& y=0\\\end{array}Î¸TXâ‰¥0Î¸TXâ‰¤0â€‹â‡’â‡’â€‹y=1y=0â€‹

The decision boundary is the line that separates the area where y=0y=0y=0 and where y=1y=1y=1. It is created by our hypothesis function.

Example:

Î¸=[5âˆ’10]\theta=\left[ \begin{array}{c}5\\-1\\0\end{array} \right]Î¸=â£â¡â€‹5âˆ’10â€‹â¦â¤â€‹

In this case, y=1y=1y=1 if 5+(âˆ’1)x1+0x2â‰¥05+(-1)x_1+0x_2 \ge 05+(âˆ’1)x1â€‹+0x2â€‹â‰¥0 , i.e. x1â‰¤5x_1 \le 5x1â€‹â‰¤5. Our boundary is a straight vertical line placed on the graph where x1=5x_1=5x1â€‹=5, and everything to the left of that denotes y=1y=1y=1, while everything to the right denotes y=0y=0y=0:

Another example:

Non-linear decision boundaries:

The input to the sigmoid function g(z) (e.g. Î¸TX\theta^TXÎ¸TX) doesnâ€™t need to be linear, and could be a function that describes a circle (e.g. z=Î¸0+Î¸1x12+Î¸2x22z=\theta_0+\theta_1x_1^2+\theta_2x_2^2z=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x12â€‹+Î¸2â€‹x22â€‹) or any shape to fit our data.

Example:

Logistic Regression Model

In this part, we will implement the logistic regression model.

TrainingÂ set:{(x(1),y(1)),(x(2),y(2)),â€¦,(x(m),y(m))}mÂ examples:xâˆˆ[x0x1â‹®xn]whereÂ (x0=1),yâˆˆ{0,1}Hypothesis:hÎ¸(x)=11+eâˆ’Î¸Tx\begin{array}{rcl}\textrm{Training set} &:& \{(x^{(1)},y^{(1)}), (x^{(2)},y^{(2)}), \ldots, (x^{(m)},y^{(m)})\}\\\\\textrm{m examples} &:&x \in \left[\begin{array}{c}x_0\\x_1\\ \vdots \\ x_n\end{array}\right] \textrm{where }(x_0=1),\quad y \in \{0,1\}\\\\\textrm{Hypothesis} &:& h_\theta(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-\theta^Tx}}\end{array}TrainingÂ setmÂ examplesHypothesisâ€‹:::â€‹{(x(1),y(1)),(x(2),y(2)),â€¦,(x(m),y(m))}xâˆˆâ£â¢â¢â¢â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹â‹®xnâ€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¥â¤â€‹whereÂ (x0â€‹=1),yâˆˆ{0,1}hÎ¸â€‹(x)=1+eâˆ’Î¸Tx1â€‹â€‹

Cost Function

If we use the same cost function that we use for linear regression (J(Î¸)=1mâˆ‘i=1m12(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2J(\theta)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m\frac{1}{2}(h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})^2J(Î¸)=m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹21â€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2) for logistic regression, it will be non-convex (that looks wavy), which is causing many local optima and hard to find the global minimum.

So, what we actually need is our new Logistic Regression Cost Function, which guarantees that J(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸) is convex for logistic regression.

J(Î¸)=1mâˆ‘i=1mCost(hÎ¸(x(i),y(i)))Cost(hÎ¸(x),y)={âˆ’log(hÎ¸(x))Â ify=1âˆ’log(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x))Â ify=0\begin{array}{l}J(\theta)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^{m}Cost(h_\theta(x^{(i)},y^{(i)}))\\\\Cost(h_\theta(x),y)=\left\{\begin{array}{rl}-log(h_\theta(x)) & \textrm{ if}\quad y=1\\-log(1-h_\theta(x)) & \textrm{ if}\quad y=0\end{array}\right.\end{array}J(Î¸)=m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹Cost(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i),y(i)))Cost(hÎ¸â€‹(x),y)={âˆ’log(hÎ¸â€‹(x))âˆ’log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x))â€‹Â ify=1Â ify=0â€‹â€‹

The â€œJ(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸)-hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x)â€ plots is like this:

Letâ€™s take a look at the Cost(hÎ¸(x),y)Cost(h_\theta(x),y)Cost(hÎ¸â€‹(x),y) :

Cost(hÎ¸(x),y)=0ifhÎ¸(x)=yCost(hÎ¸(x),y)â†’âˆify=0&hÎ¸(x)â†’1Cost(hÎ¸(x),y)â†’âˆify=1&hÎ¸(x)â†’0\begin{array}{lcl}Cost(h_\theta(x),y) = 0 &\textrm{if}& h_\theta(x)=y\\Cost(h_\theta(x),y) \to \infin &\textrm{if}& y=0 \quad\&\quad h_\theta(x) \to 1\\Cost(h_\theta(x),y) \to \infin &\textrm{if}& y=1 \quad\&\quad h_\theta(x) \to 0\\\end{array}Cost(hÎ¸â€‹(x),y)=0Cost(hÎ¸â€‹(x),y)â†’âˆCost(hÎ¸â€‹(x),y)â†’âˆâ€‹ifififâ€‹hÎ¸â€‹(x)=yy=0&hÎ¸â€‹(x)â†’1y=1&hÎ¸â€‹(x)â†’0â€‹

If our correct answer â€˜yâ€™ is 0, then the cost function will be 0 if our hypothesis function also outputs 0. If our hypothesis approaches 1, then the cost function will approach infinity.

If our correct answer â€˜yâ€™ is 1, then the cost function will be 0 if our hypothesis function outputs 1. If our hypothesis approaches 0, then the cost function will approach infinity.

Simplified Cost Function

We can simplify the CostCostCost function by compressing the two conditional cases into one case:

Cost(hÎ¸(x),y)=âˆ’yâ‹…log(hÎ¸(x))âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…log(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x))Cost(h_\theta(x),y)=-y \cdot log(h_\theta(x))-(1-y) \cdot log(1-h_\theta(x))Cost(hÎ¸â€‹(x),y)=âˆ’yâ‹…log(hÎ¸â€‹(x))âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x))

In this definition, when y=0y=0y=0, the term âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…log(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x))-(1-y) \cdot log(1-h_\theta(x))âˆ’(1âˆ’y)â‹…log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x)) will be 000; when y=0y=0y=0, the term âˆ’yâ‹…log(hÎ¸(x))-y \cdot log(h_\theta(x))âˆ’yâ‹…log(hÎ¸â€‹(x)) will be 000. Obviously, this is equal to the previous one but more easy to implement.

Now, we can fully write out our entire cost function as follow:

J(Î¸)=âˆ’1mâˆ‘i=1m[y(i)log(hÎ¸(x))+(1âˆ’y(i))log(1âˆ’hÎ¸(x(i)))]J(\theta)=-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m\Bigg[y^{(i)}log\Big(h_\theta(x)\Big)+(1-y^{(i)})log\Big(1-h_\theta(x^{(i)})\Big)\Bigg]J(Î¸)=âˆ’m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[y(i)log(hÎ¸â€‹(x))+(1âˆ’y(i))log(1âˆ’hÎ¸â€‹(x(i)))]

And a vectorized implementation is:

h=g(XÎ¸)J(Î¸)=1mâ‹…(âˆ’yTlog(h)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)Tlog(1âˆ’h))\begin{array}{l}h=g(X\theta)\\J(\theta)=\frac{1}{m}\cdot\big(-y^T log(h) -(1-y)^T log(1-h)\big)\end{array}h=g(XÎ¸)J(Î¸)=m1â€‹â‹…(âˆ’yTlog(h)âˆ’(1âˆ’y)Tlog(1âˆ’h))â€‹

Gradient Descent

The general form of gradient descent is:

Repeat{Î¸j:=Î¸jâˆ’Î±âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸jJ(Î¸)}\begin{array}{l}Repeat \quad \{\\\qquad \theta_j:=\theta_j-\alpha\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j}J(\theta)\\\}\end{array}Repeat{Î¸jâ€‹:=Î¸jâ€‹âˆ’Î±âˆ‚Î¸jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î¸)}â€‹

Work out the derivative part using calculus to get:

Repeat{Î¸j:=Î¸jâˆ’Î±mâˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))â‹…xj(i)}\begin{array}{l}Repeat \quad \{\\\qquad \theta_j:=\theta_j-\frac{\alpha}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})\cdot x_j^{(i)}\\\}\end{array}Repeat{Î¸jâ€‹:=Î¸jâ€‹âˆ’mÎ±â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))â‹…xj(i)â€‹}â€‹

Actually, this algorithm is identical to the one we used in linear regression. And notice that we still have to simultaneously update all values in theta.

Vectorized implementation:

Î¸:=Î¸âˆ’Î±mXT(g(XÎ¸)âˆ’yâ†’)\theta:=\theta-\frac{\alpha}{m}X^T(g(X\theta)-\overrightarrow{y})Î¸:=Î¸âˆ’mÎ±â€‹XT(g(XÎ¸)âˆ’yâ€‹)

Advanced Optimization

There are many more sophisticated, faster ways to optimize Î¸\thetaÎ¸ that can be used instead of gradient descent, such as â€œConjugate gradientâ€, â€œBFGSâ€ and â€œL-BFGSâ€.

We are not suggest to write these more sophisticated algorithms ourself but use the libraries instead, as theyâ€™re already tested and highly optimized. Octave provides them.

We can use octaveâ€™s fminunc() optimization algorithm to do that.

To use this advanced optimization, we first need to provide a function that evaluates the following two functions for a given inpuit value Î¸\thetaÎ¸:

J(Î¸),âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸jJ(Î¸)J(\theta), \qquad \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j}J(\theta)J(Î¸),âˆ‚Î¸jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î¸)

We can write a single function that retunrs both of these:

Then we are going to set a optimset and a initial theta as well, then send them to fminunc():

Multiclass Classification

Now we will approach the classification of data when we have more than two categories. Instead of y={0,1}y=\{0,1\}y={0,1} we will expand our definition so that y={0,1...n}y=\{0,1...n\}y={0,1...n}.

Since y={0,1...n}y=\{0,1...n\}y={0,1...n}, we divide our problem into n+1n+1n+1 (+1+1+1 because the index starts at 000) binary classification problems; in each one, we predict the probability that â€˜yyyâ€™ is a member of one of our classes.

yâˆˆ{0,1,â‹¯â€‰,n}hÎ¸(0)(x)=P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)hÎ¸(0)(x)=P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)â‹®hÎ¸(0)(x)=P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)prediction=maxÎ¸(hÎ¸(i)(x))\begin{array}{l}y \in \{0,1,\cdots,n\}\\\\h_\theta^{(0)}(x)=P(y=0|x;\theta)\\h_\theta^{(0)}(x)=P(y=0|x;\theta)\\\vdots\\h_\theta^{(0)}(x)=P(y=0|x;\theta)\\\\prediction = \mathop{max}\limits_{\theta}\big(h_\theta^{(i)}(x)\big)\end{array}yâˆˆ{0,1,â‹¯,n}hÎ¸(0)â€‹(x)=P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)hÎ¸(0)â€‹(x)=P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)â‹®hÎ¸(0)â€‹(x)=P(y=0âˆ£x;Î¸)prediction=Î¸maxâ€‹(hÎ¸(i)â€‹(x))â€‹

We are basically choosing one class and then lumping all the others into a single second class. We do this repeatedly, applying binary logistic regression to each case, and then use the hypothesis that returned the highest value as our prediction.

The following image shows how one could classify 3 classes:

To summarize:

Train a logistic regression classifier hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) for each classï¿¼ to predict the probability that ï¿¼ ï¿¼y=iy=iy=iï¿¼ ï¿¼. To make a prediction on a new xxx, pick the class ï¿¼that maximizes hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x).

entry.title: Octave å…¥é—¨
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (5) Octave Tutorial

Basic Operations

Elementary Operations

+, -, *, /, ^.

Logical Operations

==, ~=, &&, ||, xor().

Note that a not equal sign is ~=, and not !=.

Change the Prompt

We can change the prompt via PS1():

Variables

Display variables

We can also set the default length of decimal places by entering format short/long:

Create Matrices

There are some useful methods to generate matrices:

  • Generate vector of a range
  • Generate matrices of all ones/zeros
  • Generate identity matrices
  • Generate matrices of random values

Uniform distribution between 0 and 1:

Gaussian random:

We can generate a gaussian random vector with 10000 elements, and plot a histogram:

Output figure:

We can also plot a histogram with more buckets, 50 bins for example:

Get Help

Moving Data Around

Size of matrix

size(): get the size of a matrix, return [rows, columns].

length(): return the size of the longest dimension.

Load data

We can use basic shell commands to find data that we want.

load command can load data from a file.

The data from file is now comed into matrices after load

Show variables

who/whos: show variables in memory currently.

Clear variables

clear command can help us to clear variables that are no longer useful.

Save data

Take a part of a vector.

Save data to disk: save file_name variable [-ascii]

Then we can clear it from memory and load v back from disk:

Manipulate data

Get element from a matrix:

Change the elements of a matrix:

Put all elements of a matrix into a single column vector:

Computing on Data

Element-wise operations

Use .<operator> instead of <operator> for element-wise operations (i.e. operations between elements).

Element-wise comparison:

Functions are element-wise:

Floor and Ceil of elements:

Matrix operations

Matrix multiplication:

Transpose:

Get the max element of a vector | matrix:

Sum & prod of vector:

Get the diagonal elements:

Inverse:

Plotting Data

Plotting a function

It will show you a figure like this:

ğŸ‘† This will replace the sin figure with a new cos figure.

If we want to have both the sin and cos plots, the hold on command will help:

We can set some text on thw figure:

Now, we get this:

Then, we save it and close the plotting window:

We can show two figures at the same time:

Then, we can also generate figures like this:

What we need to do is using a subplot:

Use clf to clear a figure:

Showing a matrix

It gives us a figure like this:

The different colors correspond to the different values.

Another example:

Output:

Contriol Statements

for

while

if

Or, we can program like this,

break & continue

Output:

Function

Create a Function

To create a function, type the function code in a text editor (e.g. gedit or notepad), and save the file as functionName.m

Example function:

To call this function in Octave, do either:

  1. cd to the directory of the functionName.m file and call the function:
  1. Add the directory of the function file to the load path:

Function with multiple return values

Octaveâ€™s functions can return more than one value:

Practice

Letâ€™s say I have a data set that looks like this, with data points at (1, 1),(2, 2), (3, 3). And what Iâ€™d like to do is to define an octave function to compute the cost function J of theta for different values of theta.

First, put the data into octave:

Output:

Then define the cost function:

Now, use the costFunctionJ:

Got j = 0 because we set theta as [0; 1] which is fitting our data set perfectly.

Vectorization

Vectorization is the process of taking code that relies on loops and converting it into matrix operations. It is more efficient, more elegant, and more concise.

As an example, letâ€™s compute our prediction from a hypothesis. Theta is the vector of fields for the hypothesis and x is a vector of variables.

With loops:

With vectorization:

If you recall the definition multiplying vectors, youâ€™ll see that this one operation does the element-wise multiplication and overall sum in a very concise notation.

entry.title: æ­£è§„æ–¹ç¨‹
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (4) Normal Equation

Normal Equation

Gradient dedcent gives one way of minimizing our cost function JJJ. Letâ€™s discuss a second way of doing so â€“ Normal Equation.

Normal Equation minimize JJJ by explicitly taking its derivatives with resspect to the Î¸j\theta_jÎ¸jâ€‹s, and setting them to zero. This alllows us to find the optimum theta without resorting to an iteration.

The normal equation formula is given below:

Î¸=(XTX)âˆ’1XTy\theta = (X^TX)^{-1}X^TyÎ¸=(XTX)âˆ’1XTy

There is no need to do feature scaling with the normal equation.

Example

Normal Equation V.S. Gradient Descent

Gradient DescentNormal Equation
Need to choose alphaNo need to choose alpha
Needs many iterationsNo need to iterate
Time cost: O(kn2)O(kn^2)O(kn2)Need to calculate inverse of XTXX^TXXTX, which costs O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3)
Works well when n is largeSlow if n is very large

In practice, when n>10,000n > 10,000n>10,000, we are tend to use gradient descent, otherwise, normal equation will perform better.

Normal Equation Noninvertibility

When implementing the normal equation in octave we want to usr the ** pinv** function rather than inv. The pinv will give you a value of Î¸\thetaÎ¸ even if XTXX^TXXTX is not invertible.

if XTXX^TXXTX is non-invertible, the common causes might be having:

  • Redundant features, where two features are linearly dependent. (e.g. there are the size of house in feet^2 and the size of house in meter^2, where we know that 1 meter = 3.28 feet)
  • Too many features (mâ‰¤nm \le nmâ‰¤n). In this case, delete some features or use â€œregularizationâ€.

Solutions to the above problems include deleting a feature that is linearly dependent with another or deleting one or more features when there are too many features.

entry.title: å¤šå˜é‡çº¿æ€§å›å½’
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (3) Multivariate Linear Regression

Multiple Features

Linear regression with multiple variables is alse known as â€œmultivariate linear regressionâ€.

Notations

We now introduce notation for equations where we can have any number of input variables (Multiple Features, i.e. Multivariate):

  • mmm: the number of training examples.
  • nnn: the number of features.
  • x(i)x^{(i)}x(i): the input (features) of the ithi^{th}ith training example, a n-dimensional vector.
  • xj(i)x^{(i)}_jxj(i)â€‹: the value of feature jjj in the ithi^{th}ith training example.

Hypothesis

The multivariable form of the hypothesis function accommodating these multiple features is as follows:

hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1x1+Î¸2x2+Î¸3x3+...+Î¸nxnh_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1x_1+\theta_2x_2+\theta_3x_3+ ... + \theta_nx_nhÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x1â€‹+Î¸2â€‹x2â€‹+Î¸3â€‹x3â€‹+...+Î¸nâ€‹xnâ€‹

In order to develop intuition about this function, we can think about Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ as the basic price of a house, Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ as the price per square meter, Î¸2\theta_2Î¸2â€‹ as the price per floor, etc. x1x_1x1â€‹ will be the number of square meters in the house, x2x_2x2â€‹ the number of floors, etc.

Using the definition of matrix muyltiplication, our multivariable hypothesis function can be concisely represented as:

hÎ¸(x)=[Î¸0Î¸1â€¦Î¸n][x0x1â‹®xn]=Î¸Txh_\theta(x)=\left[\begin{array}{c}\theta_0 & \theta_1 & \ldots & \theta_n\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}x_0 \\ x_1 \\ \vdots \\ x_n \end{array}\right]=\theta^TxhÎ¸â€‹(x)=[Î¸0â€‹â€‹Î¸1â€‹â€‹â€¦â€‹Î¸nâ€‹â€‹]â£â¢â¢â¢â¡â€‹x0â€‹x1â€‹â‹®xnâ€‹â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¥â¤â€‹=Î¸Tx

This is a vectorization of our hypothesis function for one training example.

Remark: Note that for convenience reasons, we assume x0(i)=1for(iâˆˆ1,...,m)x^{(i)}_0=1 \quad \textrm{for(}i \in 1, ...,m \textrm{)}x0(i)â€‹=1for(iâˆˆ1,...,m). This allows us to do matrix operations with Î¸\thetaÎ¸ and xxx. Hence making two vector Î¸\thetaÎ¸ and x(i)x^{(i)}x(i) match each other element-wise (that is, have the same number of elements: n+1).

Gradient Descent For Multiple Variables

Letâ€™s say the condition about the multiple variables:

Hypothesis: hÎ¸(x)=âˆ‘i=0mÎ¸ixih_\theta(x)=\sum_{i=0}^m \theta_ix_ihÎ¸â€‹(x)=âˆ‘i=0mâ€‹Î¸iâ€‹xiâ€‹.

Parameters: Î¸0,Î¸1,...,Î¸n\theta_0, \theta_1, ...,\theta_nÎ¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹,...,Î¸nâ€‹.

Cost Function: J(Î¸0,Î¸1,...,Î¸n)=12mâˆ‘i=1m(hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2J(\theta_0, \theta_1, ..., \theta_n)=\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{i=1}^m(h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)})^2J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹,...,Î¸nâ€‹)=2m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹(hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i))2.

Or vectorizedly:

Hypothesis: hÎ¸(x)=Î¸Txh_\theta(x)=\theta^TxhÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸Tx.

Parameters: Î¸\thetaÎ¸.

Cost Function: J(Î¸)=12mâˆ‘i=1m(Î¸Tx(i)âˆ’y(i))2J(\theta)=\frac{1}{2m}\sum_{i=1}^m(\theta^Tx^{(i)}-y^{(i)})^2J(Î¸)=2m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹(Î¸Tx(i)âˆ’y(i))2.

The Gradient Descent will be like this:

repeat until convergence {

Î¸j:=Î¸jâˆ’Î±1mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]â‹…xj(i)forÂ j:=0,...,n\qquad \theta_j := \theta_j - \alpha \frac{1}{m} \sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}] \cdot x_j^{(i)}\qquad \textrm{for }j:=0, ..., nÎ¸jâ€‹:=Î¸jâ€‹âˆ’Î±m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]â‹…xj(i)â€‹forÂ j:=0,...,n

}

The following image compares gradient descent with one variable to gradient descent with multiple variables:

Feature Scaling

We can speed up gradient descent by having each of our input values in roughly the same range. This is because Î¸\thetaÎ¸ will descend quickly on small ranges and slowly on large ranges, and so will oscillate inefficiently down to the optimum when the variables are very uneven.

The way to prevent this is to modify the ranges of our input variables so that they are all roughly the same. Ideally:

âˆ’1â‰¤xiâ‰¤1orâˆ’0.5â‰¤xiâ‰¤0.5\begin{array}{c}-1 \le x_{i} \le 1\\\textrm{or}\\-0.5 \le x_{i} \le 0.5\end{array}âˆ’1â‰¤xiâ€‹â‰¤1orâˆ’0.5â‰¤xiâ€‹â‰¤0.5â€‹

These arenâ€™t exact requirements; we are only trying to speed things up. The goal is to get all input variables into roughly one of these ranges, give or take a few.

In practice, we offen think itâ€™s ok for variables in range [âˆ’3,âˆ’13)âˆª(+13,+3][-3,-\frac{1}{3}) \cup (+\frac{1}{3}, +3][âˆ’3,âˆ’31â€‹)âˆª(+31â€‹,+3].

Two techniques to help with this are feature scaling and mean normalization.

Feature scaling

Feature scaling involves dividing the input values by the range (i.e. the maximum value minus the minimum value) of input variable, resulting in a new range of just 1.

Range:si=max(xi)âˆ’min(xi)Scaling:xi:=xisi\begin{array}{rl}\textrm{Range:} & s_i = max(x_i)-min(x_i)\\\textrm{Scaling:} & x_i:=\frac{x_i}{s_i}\end{array}Range:Scaling:â€‹siâ€‹=max(xiâ€‹)âˆ’min(xiâ€‹)xiâ€‹:=siâ€‹xiâ€‹â€‹â€‹

Mean normalization

Mean normalization involves subtracting the average value for an input variable from the values for that input variable resulting in a new average value for the input variable of just zero.

Average:Î¼i=sum(xi)mMeanÂ normalizing:xi:=xiâˆ’Î¼i\begin{array}{rl}\textrm{Average:} & \mu_i = \frac{sum(x_i)}{m}\\\textrm{Mean normalizing:} & x_i:=x_i-\mu_i\end{array}Average:MeanÂ normalizing:â€‹Î¼iâ€‹=msum(xiâ€‹)â€‹xiâ€‹:=xiâ€‹âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹â€‹

Implement

We always implement both of these techniques via adjusting our input values as shown in this formula:

xi:=xiâˆ’Î¼isix_i:=\frac{x_i-\mu_i}{s_i}xiâ€‹:=siâ€‹xiâ€‹âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹â€‹

  • Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹ is the average of all the values for feature (i)
  • sis_isiâ€‹ is the range of values (max - min), or sis_isiâ€‹ could also be the standard deviation.

For example, if xix_ixiâ€‹ represents housing prices with a range of 100 to 2000 and a mean value of 1000, then, xi:=priceâˆ’10001900x_i := \dfrac{price-1000}{1900}xiâ€‹:=1900priceâˆ’1000â€‹.

In octave

In octave, the function mean can offer us the avaerage of values for feature (i), when the function std gives us the standard deviation of values for feature (i). So we can program like this:

Learning Rate

Debugging gradient descent

Make a plot with number of iterations on the x-axis. Now plot the cost functiong J(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸) over the number of iterations of gradient descent. If J(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸) ever increases, then you probably need to decrease learning rate Î±\alphaÎ±.

Automatic convergence test

Declare convergence if J(Î¸)J(\theta)J(Î¸) decreases by less than Ïµ\epsilonÏµ, where Ïµ\epsilonÏµ is some small value such as 10âˆ’310^{-3}10âˆ’3. However in practice itâ€™s difficult to choose this threshold value.

Making sure gradient descent is working correctly

It has been proven that if learning rate Î± is sufficiently small, then J(Î¸) will decrease on every iteration.

To summarize:

If Î±\alphaÎ± is too small: slow convergence.

If Î±\alphaÎ± is too large: ï¿¼may not decrease on every iteration and thus may not converge.

Implement

We should try different Î±\alphaÎ± to find a fit one by drawing #iterations-J(Î¸) plots.

E.g. To choose Î±\alphaÎ±, try:

Features and Polynomial Regression

Combine Features

We can improve our features and the form of our hypothesis function in a couple different ways.

For example, we can combine multiple features into one, Such as combining x1x_1x1â€‹ and x2x_2x2â€‹ into a new feature x3x_3x3â€‹ by taking x1â‹…x2x_1 \cdot x_2x1â€‹â‹…x2â€‹.

Polynomial Regression

To fit the data well, our hypothesis function may need to be non-linear. So we can change the behavior or curve of our hypothesis function by making it a quadratic, cubic or square root function (or any other form).

For example, if our hypothesis function is hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1x1h_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1x_1hÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x1â€‹ then we can create additional features based on x1x_1x1â€‹, to get the quadratic function hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1x1+Î¸2x12h_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1x_1+\theta_2x_1^2hÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x1â€‹+Î¸2â€‹x12â€‹ or the cubic function hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1x1+Î¸2x12+Î¸3x13h_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1x_1+\theta_2x_1^2+\theta_3x_1^3hÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x1â€‹+Î¸2â€‹x12â€‹+Î¸3â€‹x13â€‹, to make it a square root function, we could do: hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1x1+Î¸2x1h_\theta(x) = \theta_0 + \theta_1 x_1 + \theta_2 \sqrt{x_1}hÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x1â€‹+Î¸2â€‹x1â€‹â€‹.

In the cubic version, we can create new features x2x_2x2â€‹, x3x_3x3â€‹ where x2=x12x_2=x_1^2x2â€‹=x12â€‹ and x3=x13x_3=x_1^3x3â€‹=x13â€‹, then we can get a set of thetas via gradient descent for multiple variables.

âš ï¸Note. if you choose your features this way then feature scaling becomes very important.

e.g. if x has range 1 ~ 1000:

Then range of x^2 becomes 1 ~ 1000000;

And range of x^3 becomes 1 ~ 1000000000;

entry.title: çº¿æ€§ä»£æ•°å¤ä¹
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (2) Linear Algebra Review

Matrices and Vectors

  • Matrices are 2-dimensional arrays:

[abcdefghijkl]\left[\begin{array}{ccc}a & b & c \\d & e & f \\g & h & i \\j & k & l \\\end{array}\right]â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹adgjâ€‹behkâ€‹cfilâ€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹

The above matrix has four rows and three columns, so it is a 4 x 3 matrix.

  • Vector are matrices with one column and many rows:

[wxyz]\left[\begin{array}{c}w \\x \\y \\z \\\end{array}\right]â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹wxyzâ€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹

The above vector is a 4 x 1 matrix.

Notation and terms

  • AijA_{ij}Aijâ€‹ refers to the element in the ith row and jth column of matrix A.
  • A vector with â€˜nâ€™ rows is referred to as a 'n'-dimensional vector.
  • viv_iviâ€‹ refers to the element in the ith row of the vector.
  • In general, all our vectors and matrices will be 1-indexed, which refers that itâ€™s beginning from 1. Note that this is different to lots of programming languages.
  • Matrices are usualy denoted by uppercase names while vectors are lowercase.
  • Scalar means that an object is a single value, not a vector or matrix.
  • R\RR referss to the set of scalar real numbers.
  • RnR^nRn refers to the set of n-dimensional vectors of real numbers.

in Octave/Matlab

Output:

Addition and Scalar Multiplication

Addition

Addition and subtraction are element-wise, so you simply add or subtract each corresponding element:

[abcd]+[wxyz]=[a+wb+xc+yd+z]\left[\begin{array}{cc}a & b \\c & d \\\end{array}\right]+\left[\begin{array}{cc}w & x\\y & z\\\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}a+w & b+x \\c+y & d+z \\\end{array}\right][acâ€‹bdâ€‹]+[wyâ€‹xzâ€‹]=[a+wc+yâ€‹b+xd+zâ€‹]

To add or subtract two matrices, their dimensions must be the same.

Scalar multiplication

In scalar multiplication, we simply multiply every element by the scalar value:

[abcd]âˆ—x=[axbxcxdx]\left[\begin{array}{cc}a & b \\c & d \\\end{array}\right]*x=\left[\begin{array}{cc}ax & bx \\cx & dx \\\end{array}\right][acâ€‹bdâ€‹]âˆ—x=[axcxâ€‹bxdxâ€‹]

in Octave/Matlab

Output:

Matrix-Vector Multiplication

We map the column of the vector onto each row of the matrix, multiplying each element and summing the result.

[abcdef]âˆ—[xy]=[axbycxdyexfy]\left[\begin{array}{cc}a & b\\c & d\\e & f\\\end{array}\right]*\left[\begin{array}{c}x\\y\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}ax & by\\cx & dy\\ex & fy\\\end{array}\right]â£â¡â€‹aceâ€‹bdfâ€‹â¦â¤â€‹âˆ—[xyâ€‹]=â£â¡â€‹axcxexâ€‹bydyfyâ€‹â¦â¤â€‹

The result is a vector. The number of columns of the matrix must equal the number of rows of the vector.

An m x n matrix multiplied by an n x 1 vector results in an m x 1 vector.

in Octave/Matlab

Output:

Neat Trick

Say, we have a set of four sizes of houses, and we have a hypotheses for predictiong what the price of a house. We are going to compute h(x)h(x)h(x) of each of our 4 houses:

House sizes:

210414161534852\begin{array}{c}2104\\1416\\1534\\852\\\end{array}210414161534852â€‹

Hypothesis:

hÎ¸(x)=âˆ’40+0.25xh_\theta(x)=-40+0.25xhÎ¸â€‹(x)=âˆ’40+0.25x

It turns out thereâ€™s neat way of posing this, applying this hypothesis to all of my houses at the same time via a Matrix-Vector multiplication.

  • Construct a DataMatrix:

DataMatrix=[1210411416115341852]\textrm{DataMatrix}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & 2104\\1 & 1416\\1 & 1534\\1 & 852\\\end{array}\right]DataMatrix=â£â¢â¢â¡â€‹1111â€‹210414161534852â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹

  • Put Parameters to a vector:

Parameters=[âˆ’400.25]\textrm{Parameters}=\left[\begin{array}{c}-40\\0.25\\\end{array}\right]Parameters=[âˆ’400.25â€‹]

  • Then, the Predictions will be clear by calculate a Matrix-Vector Multiplication:

Predictions=DataMatrixâˆ—Parameters=[1210411416115341852]âˆ—[âˆ’400.25]\begin{array}{ccccc}\textrm{Predictions} & = & \textrm{DataMatrix} & * & \textrm{Parameters}\\ & = & \left[\begin{array}{cc}1 & 2104\\1 & 1416\\1 & 1534\\1 & 852\end{array}\right] & * & \left[\begin{array}{c}-40\\0.25\end{array}\right]\end{array}Predictionsâ€‹==â€‹DataMatrixâ£â¢â¢â¡â€‹1111â€‹210414161534852â€‹â¦â¥â¥â¤â€‹â€‹âˆ—âˆ—â€‹Parameters[âˆ’400.25â€‹]â€‹

The reuslt will be something like this:

Predictions=[âˆ’40Ã—1+0.25Ã—2104âˆ’40Ã—1+0.25Ã—1416â‹®]\textrm{Predictions}=\left[\begin{array}{c}-40 \times 1 + 0.25 \times 2104\\-40 \times 1 + 0.25 \times 1416\\\vdots\end{array}\right]Predictions=â£â¢â¡â€‹âˆ’40Ã—1+0.25Ã—2104âˆ’40Ã—1+0.25Ã—1416â‹®â€‹â¦â¥â¤â€‹

Obviously, itâ€™s equal to the codes below:

However, our new trick simplifies the code, makes it more readable as well as driving it faster to be solved in most programming languages, we just construct two matrices and do a multiplication:

Matrix-Matrix Multiplication

We multiply two matrices by breaking it into serveral vector multiplications and concatenating the result.

[abcdef]âˆ—[wxyz]=[aw+byax+bzcw+dycx+dzew+fyex+fz]\left[\begin{array}{cc}a & b\\c & d\\e & f\\\end{array}\right]*\left[\begin{array}{cc}w & x\\y & z\\\end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc}aw+by & ax+bz\\cw+dy & cx+dz\\ew+fy & ex+fz\\\end{array}\right]â£â¡â€‹aceâ€‹bdfâ€‹â¦â¤â€‹âˆ—[wyâ€‹xzâ€‹]=â£â¡â€‹aw+bycw+dyew+fyâ€‹ax+bzcx+dzex+fzâ€‹â¦â¤â€‹

An m x n matrix multiplied by an n x o matrix result in an m x o matrix ([mÃ—n]âˆ—[nÃ—o]=[mÃ—o][m \times n]*[n \times o]=[m \times o][mÃ—n]âˆ—[nÃ—o]=[mÃ—o]). In the above example, a 3 x 2 matrix times a 2 x 2 matrix resulted in a 3 x 2 matrix.

To multiply two matrices, the number of columns of the first matrix must equal the number of rows of the second matrix.

in Octave/Matlab

Output:

Neat Trick

Letâ€™s say, as befor, that we have four houses, and we want to predict their prices. Ony now, we have three competing hypotheses. We want to apply all three competing hypotheses to all four Xs. It turns out we can do that very efficiently using a matrix-matrix multiplication.

Matrix Multiplication Properties

Non-commutative

Matrices are not commutative:

AÃ—Bâ‰ BÃ—AA \times B \neq B \times AAÃ—Bî€ â€‹=BÃ—A

Associative

Matrices are associative:

(AÃ—B)Ã—C=AÃ—(BÃ—C)(A \times B) \times C = A \times (B \times C)(AÃ—B)Ã—C=AÃ—(BÃ—C)

Identity matrix

Identity matrix: a matrix that simply has 1's on the diagonal (upper left to lower right diagonal) and 0's elsewhere.

I=[100010001]I=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}1 & 0 & 0\\0 & 1 & 0\\0 & 0 & 1\\\end{array}\right]I=â£â¡â€‹100â€‹010â€‹001â€‹â¦â¤â€‹

The identity matrix, when multiplied by any matrix of the same dimensions, results in the original matrix. Itâ€™s just like multiplying numbers by 1.

AÃ—I=IÃ—A=AA \times I = I \times A = AAÃ—I=IÃ—A=A

Notice that when doing A*I, the I should match the matrixâ€™s columns and when doing I*A, the I should match the matrixâ€™s rows:

AmÃ—nÃ—InÃ—n=ImÃ—mÃ—AmÃ—n=AmÃ—nA_{m \times n} \times I_{n \times n}=I_{m \times m} \times A_{m \times n} = A_{m \times n}AmÃ—nâ€‹Ã—InÃ—nâ€‹=ImÃ—mâ€‹Ã—AmÃ—nâ€‹=AmÃ—nâ€‹

in Octave/Matlab

Output:

Inverse and Transpose

Inverse

The inverse of a matrix AAA is denoted Aâˆ’1A^{-1}Aâˆ’1. Multiplying by the inverse results in the identity matrix:

AmÃ—mÃ—AmÃ—mâˆ’1=AmÃ—mâˆ’1Ã—AmÃ—m=ImÃ—mA_{m \times m} \times A^{-1}_{m \times m}=A^{-1}_{m \times m} \times A_{m \times m} = I_{m \times m}AmÃ—mâ€‹Ã—AmÃ—mâˆ’1â€‹=AmÃ—mâˆ’1â€‹Ã—AmÃ—mâ€‹=ImÃ—mâ€‹

A non square matrix does not have an inverse matrix. We can compute inverses of matrices in octave with the pinv(A) function and in Matlab with the inv(A) function. Matrices that donâ€™t have an inverse are singular or degenerate.

In practice, when we are using normal equation with Octave, there are two functions to inverse a Matrix â€“ pinv and inv. For some mathematically reason, The pinv(A) will always offer us the value of data that we want, even if A is non-invertible.

Transpose

The transposition of a matrix is like rotating the matrix 90Âº in clockwise direction and then reversing it.

In other words: Let AAA be an mÃ—nm \times nmÃ—n matrix, and let B=ATB=A^TB=AT. Then BBB is an nÃ—mn \times mnÃ—m matrix, and Bij=AjiB_{ij}=A_{ji}Bijâ€‹=Ajiâ€‹.

A=[abcdef]AT=[acebdf]A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}a & b\\c & d\\e & f\\\end{array}\right]\qquadA^T=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}a & c & e\\b & d & f\\\end{array}\right]A=â£â¡â€‹aceâ€‹bdfâ€‹â¦â¤â€‹AT=[abâ€‹cdâ€‹efâ€‹]

We can compute transposition of matrices in matlab with the transpose(A) function or A'

in Octave/Matlab

Output:

entry.title: golang-æ›´å¤šç±»å‹ï¼šæŒ‡é’ˆã€structã€sliceå’Œæ˜ å°„
entry.content:
æ›´å¤šç±»å‹ï¼šæŒ‡é’ˆã€structã€slice å’Œæ˜ å°„

Â§ æŒ‡é’ˆ

Go æ‹¥æœ‰æŒ‡é’ˆã€‚æŒ‡é’ˆä¿å­˜äº†å€¼çš„å†…å­˜åœ°å€ã€‚

ç±»å‹ *T æ˜¯æŒ‡å‘ T ç±»å‹å€¼çš„æŒ‡é’ˆã€‚å…¶é›¶å€¼ä¸º nilã€‚

& æ“ä½œç¬¦ä¼šç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªæŒ‡å‘å…¶æ“ä½œæ•°çš„æŒ‡é’ˆã€‚

* æ“ä½œç¬¦è¡¨ç¤ºæŒ‡é’ˆæŒ‡å‘çš„åº•å±‚å€¼ã€‚

è¿™ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯é€šå¸¸æ‰€è¯´çš„â€œé—´æ¥å¼•ç”¨â€æˆ–â€œé‡å®šå‘â€ã€‚

ä¸ C ä¸åŒï¼ŒGo æ²¡æœ‰æŒ‡é’ˆè¿ç®—ã€‚

è¾“å‡ºï¼š

Â§ ç»“æ„ä½“

ä¸€ä¸ªç»“æ„ä½“ï¼ˆstructï¼‰å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ç»„å­—æ®µï¼ˆfieldï¼‰ã€‚

è¾“å‡ºï¼š

ç»“æ„ä½“å­—æ®µ

ç»“æ„ä½“å­—æ®µä½¿ç”¨ç‚¹å·æ¥è®¿é—®ã€‚

è¾“å‡ºï¼š

ç»“æ„ä½“æŒ‡é’ˆ

ç»“æ„ä½“å­—æ®µå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ç»“æ„ä½“æŒ‡é’ˆæ¥è®¿é—®ã€‚

å¦‚æœæˆ‘ä»¬æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæŒ‡å‘ç»“æ„ä½“çš„æŒ‡é’ˆ pï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡ (*p).X æ¥è®¿é—®å…¶å­—æ®µ Xã€‚ä¸è¿‡è¿™ä¹ˆå†™å¤ªå•°å—¦äº†ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è¯­è¨€ä¹Ÿå…è®¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨éšå¼é—´æ¥å¼•ç”¨ï¼Œç›´æ¥å†™ p.X å°±å¯ä»¥ã€‚
