entry.title: å•å˜é‡çº¿æ€§å›å½’
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (1) Linear Regression with One Variable

Model Representation

Notation

  • x(i)x^{(i)}x(i) denote the input variables, called input features
  • y(i)y^{(i)}y(i) denote the output variables, called target variable
  • (x(i),y(i))(x^{(i)}, y^{(i)})(x(i),y(i)) is called a training example
  • (x(i),y(i));i=1,...,m(x^{(i)}, y^{(i)}); i=1, ..., m(x(i),y(i));i=1,...,m â€”â€” is called a training set

âš ï¸ã€Noteã€‘The superscript â€œ(i)^{(i)}(i)â€ in the notations is simply an index into the train set.

  • XXX denote the space of input values
  • YYY denote the space of output values

In many examples, X=Y=RX = Y =\RX=Y=R.

A more formal description of supervised learning

Given a training set, to learn a function h:Xâ†’Yh: X \to Yh:Xâ†’Y so that h(x)h(x)h(x) is a â€œgoodâ€ predictor for the corresponding value of yyy.

For historical reasons, this function hhh is called a hypothesis.

Pictorially:

With our new notations, the categories of supervised learning problems can be this:

  • regression problem: when the target variable is continuous.
  • classification problem: yyy can take on only a small number of discrete values

Hypothesis & Model Regression

To represent the hypothesis hhh, for example, if we want to fit a data set like this:

Simply, we may make the hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1xh_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1xhÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x. This is means that we are going to predict that yyy is a linear function of xxx.

Plotting this in the picture, it will be something like this:

And what this function is doing is predicting that yyy is some straight line function of xxx.

In this case, this model is called linear regression with one variable(or Univariate linear regression).

P.S. we can also fit a more complicated (perhaps non-linear) functions, but this linear case is the simplest.

Cost Function

Well, now we have got this:

To get a â€œgoodâ€ hypothesis function, we need to choose Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹, Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ so that hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) is close to yyy for our training exmaples (x,y)(x, y)(x,y). A cost function is of great help with this goal.

Cost function

A cost function can help us to measure the accuracy of our hypothesis function.

This takes an average difference of all the results of the hypothesis with inputs from xâ€™s and the actual output yâ€™s:

J(Î¸0,Î¸1)=12mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2(1)J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = \frac{1}{2m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]^2 \tag{1}J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)=2m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2(1)

The function (1)(1)(1) is our cost function exactly. Take a look at it:

  • hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i) shows the difference between the predicted value and the actual value.

  • 1mâˆ‘i=1m...\frac{1}{m}\sum^{m}_{i=1}...m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹... offers the mean of the squares of hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)

  • The mean is halved (12\frac{1}{2}21â€‹) as a convenience for the computati::on of the gradient descent, as the 12f2=f\frac{1}{2}f^2 = f21â€‹f2=f.

P.S. This function is otherwise called the â€œSquared error functionâ€, or â€œMean squared errorâ€.

Goal

To make hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) closing to yyy, we are just expected to minimize our cost function by adjusting the value of Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹, Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹.

We describe this goal like this:

minimizeÎ¸0,Î¸1J(Î¸0,Î¸1)(2)\mathop{minimize}\limits_{\theta_0, \theta_1} J(\theta_0, \theta_1) \tag{2}Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹minimizeâ€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)(2)

Or, more directly:

minimizeÎ¸0,Î¸112mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2(3)\mathop{minimize}\limits_{\theta_0, \theta_1}\frac{1}{2m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]^2\tag{3}Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹minimizeâ€‹2m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2(3)

And if we are working with a linear regression with one variable, the hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1xh_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1xhÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x.

âš ï¸ã€Noteã€‘Hypothesis Function & Cost Function

  • hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) for fixed Î¸i\theta_iÎ¸iâ€‹, is a function of xxx.
  • J(Î¸0,Î¸1)J(\theta_0, \theta_1)J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹) is a function of the parameter Î¸i\theta_iÎ¸iâ€‹ .

Cost Function - Intuition I

Letâ€™s draw some pictures for better understanding of what the values of the cost function.

To getting start, we are going to work with a simplified hypothesis function:

Our training data set is scattered on the x-y plane. We are trying to make a straight line (defined by hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x)) which passes through these scattered data points.

Our objective is to get the best possible line. The best possible line will be such:

So that the average squared vertical distances of the scattered points from the line (1mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2\frac{1}{m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]^2m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2) will be the least.

Ideally, the line should pass through all the points of our training data set. In such a case, the value of cost function J(Î¸0,Î¸1)J(\theta_0, \theta_1)J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹) will be 0.

E.g. A ideal situation where J=0J=0J=0:

Let this be our training set: Only three points (1, 1), (2, 2) & (3, 3)

Now, we try setting Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ to different values: -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1, 1.5â€¦

When Î¸1=1\theta_1=1Î¸1â€‹=1, we get a slope of 1 which goes through every single data point in our model. Conversely, when Î¸1=0.5\theta_1=0.5Î¸1â€‹=0.5, we see the vertical distance from our fit to the data points increase:

By doing this, we got a series of graph of hÎ¸(x)h_\theta(x)hÎ¸â€‹(x) in x-y plane as well as yield to the following Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹-J(Î¸1)J(\theta_1)J(Î¸1â€‹) graph:

Thus as a goal, we should try to minimize the cost function. In this case, Î¸1=1\theta_1=1Î¸1â€‹=1 is our global minimum.

Cost Function - Intuition II

Unlike before, this time, we wonâ€™t continue with the simplified hypothesis, we are going to keep both of parameters Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ and Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹. So the hypithesis function will be hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1xh_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1xhÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x.

Hereâ€™s our problem formulation as usual:

Hypothesis:Â hÎ¸(x)=Î¸0+Î¸1xParameters:Â Î¸0,Î¸1CostÂ Function:Â J(Î¸0,Î¸1)=12mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2Goal:Â minimizeÎ¸0,Î¸1J(Î¸0,Î¸1)\begin{array}{rl} \textrm{Hypothesis: } & h_\theta(x)=\theta_0+\theta_1x\\ & \\ \textrm{Parameters: } & \theta_0, \theta_1\\ & \\ \textrm{Cost Function: } & J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = \frac{1}{2m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]^2\\ & \\ \textrm{Goal: } & \mathop{minimize}\limits_{\theta_0, \theta_1} J(\theta_0, \theta_1)\end{array}Hypothesis:Â Parameters:Â CostÂ Function:Â Goal:Â â€‹hÎ¸â€‹(x)=Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹xÎ¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)=2m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹minimizeâ€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)â€‹

Same as last time, we want to unserstand the hypothesis hhh and the cost function JJJ via a series of graph. However, weâ€™d like to use a contour plot to describe our J(Î¸0,Î¸1)J(\theta_0, \theta_1)J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹).

A contour plot is a graph that contains many contour lines.

A contour line of a two variable function has a constant value at all points of the same line.

An example:

Taking any color and going along the â€˜circleâ€™, one would expect to get the same value of the cost function.

To touch our optimization objective, we can try to setting the parameters Î¸i\theta_iÎ¸iâ€‹ to different values.

When Î¸0=360\theta_0 = 360Î¸0â€‹=360 and Î¸1=0\theta_1 = 0Î¸1â€‹=0, the value of J(Î¸0,Î¸1)J(\theta_0, \theta_1)J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹) in the contour plot gets closer to the center thus reducing the cost function error. Now we get a result in a better fit of the data:

Minimizing the cost function as much as possible and consequently, the result of Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ and Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ tend to be around 0.12 and 250 respectively. Plotting those values on our graph to the right seems to put our point in the center of the inner most â€˜circleâ€™.

Obviously, we dislike to write a software to just plot out a contour plot and then try to manually read off the numbers to reach our goal. We want an efficient algorithm for automatically finding the value of Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ and Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ that minimizes the cost function JJJ. Actually, the gradient descent algorithm that we will talk about works great on this question.

Gradient Descent

There is a algorithm called gradient descent for minimizing the cost function JJJ. And we can use it not only in linear regression as itâ€™s actually used all over the place in machine learning.

Letâ€™s talk about gradient descent for minimizing some arbitrary function JJJ. So hereâ€™s the problem setup:

We put Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ on the x axis and Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ on the y axis, with the cost function on the vertical z axis. The points on our graph will be the result of the cost function using our hypothesis with those specific theta parameters. The graph below depicts such a setup:

We will know that we have succeeded when our cost function is at the very bottom of the pits in our graph, i.e. when its value is the minimum. The red arrows show the minimum points in the graph.

Image that we are physically standing at a point on a hill, in gradient descent, what weâ€™re going to do is to spin 360 degrees around and just look all around us, and ask, â€œIf I were to take a little step in some direction, and I want to go down the hill as quickly as possible, what direction should I take?â€ then you take a step in that direction. Repeat doing this until you converge to a local minimum. Like the black line in the picture above shows.

Notice that if we choose different points to grandient descent, we may reach different local optimums.

Mathematically, this is the definition of the gradient descent algorithm:

Gradient Descent Algorithm

repeat until convergence {

Î¸j:=Î¸jâˆ’Î±âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸jJ(Î¸0,Î¸1)(forÂ j=0Â andÂ j=1)\qquad\theta_j := \theta_j - \alpha\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j}J(\theta_0, \theta_1)\qquad \textrm{(for } j=0 \textrm{ and } j=1 \textrm{)}Î¸jâ€‹:=Î¸jâ€‹âˆ’Î±âˆ‚Î¸jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)(forÂ j=0Â andÂ j=1)

}

The Î±\alphaÎ± is a number that is called the learning rate. It basically controls how big a step we take downhill with gradient descent.

At each iteration jjj, one should simultaneously update the parameters Î¸1,Î¸2,â€¦,Î¸n. Updating a specific parameter prior to calculating another one on the j(th) iteration would yield to a wrong implementation:

Gradient Descent Intuition

Letâ€™s explore the scenario where we used **one parameter Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ ** and plotted its cost function to implement a gradient descent. Our formula for a single parameter was : Repeat until convergence:

Î¸1:=Î±ddÎ¸1J(Î¸1)\theta_1:=\alpha\frac{d}{d\theta_1}J(\theta_1)Î¸1â€‹:=Î±dÎ¸1â€‹dâ€‹J(Î¸1â€‹)

Regardless of the slopeâ€™s sign for ddÎ¸1J(Î¸1)\frac{d}{d\theta_1}J(\theta_1)dÎ¸1â€‹dâ€‹J(Î¸1â€‹) eventually converges to its minimum value.

The following graph shows that when the slope is negative, the value of Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ increases and when it is positive, the value of Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ decreases:

On a side note, we should adjust our parameter Î±\alphaÎ± to ensure that the gradient descent algorithm converges in a reasonable time. Failure to converge or too much time to obtain the minimum value imply that our step size is wrong.

How does gradient descent converge with a fixed step size Î±\alphaÎ±?
The intuition behind the convergence is that ddÎ¸1J(Î¸1)\frac{d}{d\theta_1}J(\theta_1)dÎ¸1â€‹dâ€‹J(Î¸1â€‹) approaches 0 as we approach the bottom of our convex function. At the minimum, the derivative will always be 0 and thus we get:

Gradient Descent for Linear Regression

Now, we have learnt the gradient descent, the linear regression model and the squared error cost function as well. This time, we are going to put together gradient descent with our cost function that will give us an algorithm for linear regression for fitting a straight line to our data.

This is what we worked out:

We are going to apply gradient descent algorithm to minimize our squared error cost function.

The key term is the derivative term:

âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸jJ(Î¸0,Î¸1)=âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸j12mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2=âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸j12mâˆ‘i=1m[Î¸0+Î¸1x(i)âˆ’y(i)]2\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j}J(\theta_0, \theta_1) = \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j}\frac{1}{2m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]^2=\frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_j}\frac{1}{2m}\sum^m_{i=1}[\theta_0+\theta_1x^{(i)}-y^{(i)}]^2âˆ‚Î¸jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)=âˆ‚Î¸jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹2m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]2=âˆ‚Î¸jâ€‹âˆ‚â€‹2m1â€‹i=1âˆ‘mâ€‹[Î¸0â€‹+Î¸1â€‹x(i)âˆ’y(i)]2

j=0:âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸0J(Î¸0,Î¸1)=1mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]j=1:âˆ‚âˆ‚Î¸1J(Î¸0,Î¸1)=1mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]â‹…x(i)\begin{array}{rl}j=0: & \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_0}J(\theta_0,\theta_1)=\frac{1}{m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]\\ & \\j=1: & \frac{\partial}{\partial\theta_1}J(\theta_0,\theta_1)=\frac{1}{m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}] \cdot x^{(i)}\end{array}j=0:j=1:â€‹âˆ‚Î¸0â€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)=m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]âˆ‚Î¸1â€‹âˆ‚â€‹J(Î¸0â€‹,Î¸1â€‹)=m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]â‹…x(i)â€‹

Plug them back into our gradient descent algorithm:

repeat until convergence {

Î¸0:=Î¸0âˆ’Î±1mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]\qquad\theta_0 := \theta_0 - \alpha\frac{1}{m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}]Î¸0â€‹:=Î¸0â€‹âˆ’Î±m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]

Î¸1:=Î¸1âˆ’Î±1mâˆ‘i=1m[hÎ¸(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]â‹…x(i)\qquad\theta_1 := \theta_1 - \alpha\frac{1}{m}\sum^m_{i=1}[h_\theta(x^{(i)})-y^{(i)}] \cdot x^{(i)}Î¸1â€‹:=Î¸1â€‹âˆ’Î±m1â€‹âˆ‘i=1mâ€‹[hÎ¸â€‹(x(i))âˆ’y(i)]â‹…x(i)

}

Notice: update Î¸0\theta_0Î¸0â€‹ and Î¸1\theta_1Î¸1â€‹ simultaneously.

The point of all this is that if we start with a guess for our hypothesis and then repeatedly apply these gradient descent equations, our hypothesis will become more and more accurate. So, this is simply gradient descent on the original cost function J.

This method looks at every example in the entire training set on every step, and is called batch gradient descent.

Note that, while gradient descent can be susceptible to local minima in general, the optimization problem we have posed here for linear regression has only one global, and no other local,optima; thus gradient descent always converges (assuming the learning rate Î± is not too large) to the global minimum. Indeed, J is a convex quadratic function. Here is an example of gradient descent as it is run to minimize a quadratic function.

The ellipses shown above are the contours of a quadratic function. Also shown is the trajectory taken by gradient descent, which was initialized at (48,30). The xâ€™s in the figure (joined by straight lines) mark the successive values of Î¸ that gradient descent went through as itconverged to its minimum.

Experiment

A Wild Implement of Linear Regression with One Variable via Gradient Descent in Python Made by Myself:

entry.title: æœºå™¨å­¦ä¹ å¼•å…¥
entry.content:
Notes of Andrew Ngâ€™s Machine Learning â€”â€” (0) Introduction

Welcome

Machine Learning

  • Grew out of work in AI
  • New capability for computers

Examples:

  • Database mining
    Large datasets from growth of automation / web.
    E.g. Web click data, medical records, biology, engineering

  • Applications canâ€™t program by hand.
    E.g. Autonomous helicopter, handwriting recognition, most of Natural Language Progressing (NLP), Computer Vision.

  • Self-customizing programs
    E.g. Amazon, Netflix product recommendations

  • Understanding human learning (brain, real AI)

What is machine learning

Machine Learning definition

  • Arthur Samuel (1959) : Machine Learning: Field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.
  • Tom Mitchell (1998), a more modern definition : Well-posed Learning Problem: A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some task T and some prformance measure P, if its performance on T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.

Example:

  • Playing checkers.

    E = the experience of playing many games of checkers
    T = the task of playing checkers.
    P = the probability that the program will win the next game.

  • Spam Filter

    E = Watching you label emails as spam or not spam
    T = Classifying emails as spam or not spam
    P = The number (or fraction) of emails correctly classified as spam / not spam.

Machine Learning algorithms

  • Supervised learning
  • Unsupervised learning

Others: Reinforcement learning, recommender system

Supervised Learning

In supervised learning, we are:

  • given a data set
  • given â€œright answersâ€ (already know what our correct output should look like)
  • having the idea that there is a relationship between the input and the output.

Categories of supervised learning problems

  1. Regression: Predict continuous valued output

    Trying to map input variables to some continuous function.

    [To predict how much]

    E.g.

    • You have a large inventory of identical items. You want to predict how many of these items will sell over the next 3 months.
    • Given a picture of a person, we have to predict their age on the basis of the given picture

  2. Classification: Discrete valued output (0/1 or 0/1/2/3â€¦)

    Trying to map input variables into discrete categories.

    [To predict whether/which]

    E.g.

    • Given a patient with a tumor, we have to predict whether the tumor is malignant or benign.
    • Youâ€™d like software to examine individual customer accounts, and for each accout decide if it has been hacked/compromised.

Unsupervised Learning

In unsupervised learning we can:

  • approach problems with little or no idea what our results should look like
  • derive structure from data where we donâ€™t necessarily know the effect of the variables.
  • derive this structure by clustering the data based on relationships among the variables in the data.

With unsupervised learning there is no feedback based on the prediction results.

E.g.

  1. Clustering:

    • Google news looks for tens of thousands of news stories and automatically cluster them together. So, the news stories that are all about the same topic get displayed together.

    • Take a collection of 1,000,000 different genes, and find a way to automatically group these genes into groups that are somehow similar or related by different variables, such as lifespan, location, roles, and so on.

  2. Non-clustering:

    The â€œCocktail Party Algorithmâ€, allows you to find structure in a chaotic environment. (i.e. identifying individual voices and music from a mesh of sounds at a cocktail party).

å®‰è£…

æ³¨å†ŒGitHub

é¦–å…ˆï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬éœ€è¦æ³¨å†Œä¸€ä¸ª GitHub è´¦æˆ·ï¼Œæˆ‘ç›¸ä¿¡ç»å¤§å¤šæ•°çš„è¯»è€…å·²ç»å®Œæˆäº†è¿™ä¸€æ­¥ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¸å†èµ˜è¿°ï¼›å¦‚æœæ‚¨å¹¸è¿çš„å±äºå°‘æ•°äººï¼Œè¯·æ‰“å¼€ GitHubï¼Œå³å¯æŒ‰ç…§æ„Ÿè§‰è½»æ¾å®Œæˆã€‚

The static keyword in Java is used for memory management mainly. We can apply java static keyword with variables, methods, blocks and nested class. The static keyword belongs to the class than an instance of the class. The static can be: Variable (also known as a class variable) Method (also known as a class method) Block.

Linux

Linux (/ËˆlÉªnÉ™ks/ LIN-É™ks) is a family of open source Unix-like operating systems based on the Linux kernel, an operating system kernel first released on September 17, 1991 by Linus Torvalds. Linux is typically packaged in a Linux distribution.

  • MacOSï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯æˆ‘ç°åœ¨æ­£åœ¨ä½¿ç”¨çš„æ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿï¼ŒAppleä¸€å‘ä»¥ç”¨æˆ·ä½“éªŒè‘—ç§°ã€‚MacOSç»å¯¹æ˜¯æˆ‘ç”¨è¿‡çš„ä½“éªŒæœ€å¥½çš„è®¡ç®—æœºæ“ä½œç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œä½ ä¸ç”¨äº†è§£å¤ªå¤šçš„ä¸œè¥¿å°±å¯ä»¥ä¸“å¿ƒåœ°é«˜æ•ˆå®Œæˆä½ çš„å·¥ä½œã€‚ä½† MacOS æ— è®ºå¦‚ä½•è¿˜æ˜¯è„±ç¦»ä¸äº† UNIX çš„å½±å“ï¼ŒUNIX æœ‰çš„é—®é¢˜ï¼ŒMacOS ä¹Ÿä¼šæœ‰ï¼Œåªæ˜¯åœ¨è¡¨é¢ä¸Šçœ‹ä¸å‡ºæ¥ã€‚åœ¨å¼€å‘æ–¹é¢ï¼ŒæŒ‰ç…§ Apple çš„æ–‡æ¡£ï¼Œä½ è™½ç„¶å¯ä»¥å¿«é€Ÿåœ°å¼€å‘å‡ºä¸€ä¸ª Appï¼Œä½†ä½ å¾ˆéš¾å»äº†è§£åº•å±‚çš„ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œè¿™ç»™ç§»æ¤ä¹‹ç±»çš„å·¥ä½œå¸¦æ¥äº†å¾ˆå¤§çš„éº»çƒ¦ï¼Œä¸è¿‡è¿‘å¹´æ¥ä¹Ÿæœ‰å¥½è½¬ã€‚

  • Windowsï¼Œæˆ‘æ‰¿è®¤å¾®è½¯å¾ˆå‰å®³ï¼ŒWindowsçš„è®¾è®¡ä¹Ÿæœ‰å¾ˆå¤šå¾ˆå¥½çš„åœ°æ–¹ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å§‹ç»ˆæ— æ³•æ¥å— Windows å‘ˆç°ç»™ç”¨æˆ·çš„é‚£ç§ä¸œè¥¿ï¼Œæˆ‘æƒ³æ˜¯æˆ‘çš„ç¨‹åºè®¾è®¡åŠŸå¤«è¿˜ä¸åˆ°å®¶ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä¸å–œæ¬¢å¾®è½¯é£æ ¼çš„ä»£ç â€”â€”è™½ç„¶å®¢è§‚åœ°è¯´æˆ‘æ‰¿è®¤å®ƒä»¬å…¶å®å¾ˆå¥½ã€‚åœ¨ Windows 10 ä¸­æˆ‘å·²ç»çœ‹åˆ°äº†å®ƒæœæˆ‘æƒ³è¦çš„æ–¹å‘æœ‰äº†åè¶³çš„è¿›æ­¥ï¼Œä½†è¿™è¿˜ä¸å¤Ÿï¼æˆ‘æœŸæœ›å¾®è½¯æœ‰ä¸€å¤©å¯ä»¥è®©æˆ‘ç”¨å› Windowsï¼Œæ¯•ç«Ÿå®ƒæ˜¯æˆ‘å¯¹è®¡ç®—æœºçš„æœ€åˆå›å¿†ã€‚
